taxonomicnotes:
Previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius marmoratus, Telmatobius hintoni was elevated to species category by De la Riva (2005) based on morphological and colour differences.

In addition to the holotype, the type series of T. hintoni is comprised of three specimens from Calacoto, La Paz, but these specimens are not conspecific with the holotype, and they were correctly identified as T. marmoratuis by Vellard (De la Riva, 2005).
rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, in view of its extent of occurrence of less than 20,000 km2, with all individuals in fewer than ten locations, and a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.

taxonomicnotes: This former subspecies was promoted to species level (Menezes et al. 2011). The two former subspecies can be found growing together in Bahia and Ceara.
rationale: There are no more than 1,000 mature individuals of Tacinga subcylindrica, with less than 100 individuals per subpopulation. The extent of occurrence is approximately 3,700 km2, the population is severely fragmented, and habitat quality as well as the number of mature individuals are declining. The main threats to the species are collection as well as habitat destruction by mining and deforestation for agricultural purposes. A population decline of 30 percent has occurred over the last two generations and is assumed to continue at an even higher rate. The threats are known, but are not reversible. The species is therefore assessed as Endangered.
assessor: Machado, M., Taylor, N.P., Zappi, D. & Braun, P.

taxonomicnotes: Astacus leptodactylus is referred to as a species complex. In the 1950s this species was believed to belong to the subgenus Astacus (Potastacus) along with A. (P.) pachypus, A. (P.) pylzowi and A. (P.) kessleri.The following four subspecies were attributed to A. (P.) leptodactylus: eichwaldi, cubanicus, salinus, and leptodactylus. Karaman (1962, 1963) however does not acknowledge A. (P.) cubanicus as a subspecies. In the 1970s, Pontastacus was raised to generic level. In the 1980s, Brodskij made a number of revisions within Pontastacus but the number of taxa varied within papers. In the mid 1990s Starobogatov (1995) split Pontastacus into two genera: Pontastacus - P. angulosus (Rathke, 1837); P. cubanicus (Birstein & Winogradow, 1934); P. danubialis (Brodskij, 1967); P. eichwaldi (Bott, 1950); P. intermedius (Bott, 1950); P. kessleri (Schimkewitsch, 1886); P. pyzlowi (Skorikov, 1911); P. salinus (Nordmann, 1942), and Caspiastacus with two species. However, there is great deal of criticism over the recent revision in taxonomy made by Ukranian and Russian taxonomists as it appears to be based on little evidence.
rationale: Astacus leptodactylus has been assessed as Least Concern. This species is native to the eastern European countries where it is widespread and abundant. It has suffered significant declines both in the past and in the present day, however the majority of the population appears to be relatively stable.

taxonomicnotes: Herler et al. (2005) clarified the status of G. fallax Sarato (1889).
rationale: Gobius fallax is known from several localities along the northern Mediterranean coast and from a single Atlantic record from the Canaries. It is reported to be common in parts of its range and is not known to have any major threats. Therefore, G. fallax is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Kovacic, M., Williams, J.T. & Herler, J.
evaluator: Ahnelt, H., Larson, H. & Harvey, M.

rationale: Chromogobius quadrivittatus is distributed throughout the northern and eastern Mediterranean Sea and from parts of the western and northern Black Sea. Little data are available on the population size, but there are no known major threats to C. quadrivittatus. Therefore, C. quadrivittatus is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Kovacic, M., Herler, J. & Williams, J.T.
evaluator: Ahnelt, H., Larson, H. & Harvey, M.

taxonomicnotes: Two varieties are recognized: the nominate boeckeleriana and transiens (K.Schum.) R.Haines.
rationale: Bulbostylis boeckeleriana is assessed as Least Concern. The species has an extensive distribution range, it occurs across eastern Africa, from Ethiopia to South Africa, and is common where it is found. The population is currently believed to be stable and no real threats are known at present and the species appears to be tolerant of some disturbance.
assessor: Contu, S. & IUCN SSC East African Plants Red List Authority

taxonomicnotes: In the flora of Quézel and Santa (1962-63), Alopecurus arundinaceus is given as Alopecurus pratensis. There are two sub-species: ssp. nigricans that is quite rare in the western part of the high plateaux, and ssp. brachystachys which is found in several phytogeographical regions.
rationale: This species is locally abundant and without any major threats in the Mediterranean, which makes up a large part of its range. Populations in some countries are very sparse and may be affected by stochastic events. Therefore, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.

taxonomicnotes:
Agrostis stolonifera L. is a wild relative of the cultivated form, creeping bent grass.

Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly (2009) recognize seven subspecies which are native to Europe: A. stolonifera ssp. albida (Trin.) Tzvelev, A. stolonifera ssp. filfiolia (Link) H. Scholz, A. stolonifera ssp. gaditana (Boiss. & Reut.) Valdés & H. Scholz, A. stolonifera ssp. maritima (Lam.) Vasc., A. stolonifera ssp. scabriglumis (Boiss. & Reut.) Maire, A. stolonifera ssp. stolonifera and A. stolonifera ssp. straminea (Hartm.) Tzvelev. However, the subordinate taxa are poorly defined and taxonomic recognition between authors is inconsistent. It is therefore unlikely that taxonomic issues will affect the conservation or Red List assessment of this species.
rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.

taxonomicnotes: There are three subspecies within Callitriche truncata: ssp. occidentalis is common and increasing, ssp. truncata is little-known and poorly understood and ssp. fimbriata is a local endemic to a very small area and probably endangered, but is so little known that it is impossible to assess its status.
rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats. However, two of its subspecies are either very poorly known or decreasing.

taxonomicnotes:
Although there is some uncertainty regarding the taxonomy of populations close to A. plantago-aquatica in Asia, these do not affect evaluation of the species in Europe.

Plants with the leaves similar to that of A. plantago-aquatica, styles as in A. gramineum and 0.2-0.3 mm long undeveloped anthers are known from Orenburg Region (basin of the Ural and Samara Rivers). Apparently this is the result of hybridization of A. plantago-aquatica × A. gramineum and possibly sterile. These are known as A. ×bjorkqvistii Tzvel. (Tzvelev 2001). This hybridisation is not sufficiently frequent to affect evaluation of the species.

A. plantago-aquatica is reported to hybridise occasionally with A. lanceolatum (A. ×rhicnocarpum Schotsm.) but this is not sufficiently frequent to affect evaluation of the species in Europe.
rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.

taxonomicnotes: There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. A. aequalis has been shown to hybridise with A. geniculatus (A. ×haussknechtianus Asch. & Graebn.) which occurs fairly frequently in areas of sympatry but is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.

rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations throughout most of its range and does not face any major threats.

Thelypteris interrupta is widely distributed and commonly occurring with no threats, hence assessed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Rajesh, K.P., Manju, C.N., Jeeva, S. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name in Europe but there are some taxonomic issues to do with American populations.
rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.

taxonomicnotes: G. notata has been shown to hybridise with G. fluitans (G. ×pedicellata F. Towns.), however, although this hybrid is locally frequent and it is not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
rationale: This species is classed as Least Concern as it is widespread with stable populations and does not face any major threats.

taxonomicnotes: The nominative subspecies M. r. russowi is distributed in Central Asia and Kazakhstan. The subspecies M. r. zarudnyi (Nikolsky, 1900) occurs in northeastern and eastern Iran (Khorasan and Sistan Provinces). It is possible that the subspecific form M. r. kopalensis (Shnitnikov, 1928) from Kazakhstan will be revalidated as a species following additional biochemical and molecular research.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, it occurs in a number of protected areas, has a tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Ananjeva, N., Orlov, N., Papenfuss, T. & Shafiei Bafti, S.
evaluator: Cox, N., Temple, H.J. (Global Reptile Assessment Coordinating Team) & Böhm, M., Collen, B., Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

taxonomicnotes: Gobiobotia kolleri was originally described from Hainan Island (Banarescu & Nalbant, 1966). In a revision of Chinese species, He & Chen (in Chen, 1998) treat it as endemic to Hainan. The identity of the material recorded by Vietnamese authors need confirmation (Kottelat 2001).
rationale: Gobiobotia kolleri has been assessed as Data Deficient, due to a lack of information regarding species' population trends and direct threats to this species.

taxonomicnotes:
Takifugu ocellatus (Linnaeus, 1758)

Vietnamese named: Cá Nóc ch?m.
Synonyms:

Diodon  ocellatus (Linnaeus, 1758); Tetraodon ocellatus Chevey & Lemasson, 1937; Fugu ocellatus Matsubara, 1955
Discrible by Mai, 1978: L = 78-123mm, Lo = 63 - 102mm. D = 4,11; A = 3,10; P = 2,16; V = 0; C = 1+8+2. Lo = 3,47 H = 3,62 T; T = 3,62 O = 4,61 OO.

Round, flat side and long body, large dorsal and head. Many flaxes on body. Flaxes of dorsal distributed from back 2 nostrils to front dorsal fin. Round caudal peduncle, high body, small mouth and strong teeth. Large eyes on 2 sides head. Lateral line has 3 sections. Dorsal fin put off body. Draw anal fin. Has not pelvic fin, large pectoral fin. Brown dorsal, silver abdomen. Has 2 large points eyes after pectoral fin. And 1 large point on dorsal fin.

Specimens have been keeping at the Museum of Animals of Natural Sciences University - Hanoi National of Universtity.
rationale: Takifugu ocellatus is distributed in the northwest Pacific in coastal areas of China south to Viet Nam and South Korea at depths ranging from very shallow waters to 20 metres. It is an anadromous species which undergoes seasonal annual migrations to freshwater to spawn. It does not appear to be overly common, and is considered rare in parts of its range. Takifugu ocellatus is a highly-valued food fish, and has been the subject of artificial breeding efforts in China and South Korea for the purposes of stock enhancement and in order to supply fish for human consumption. This species' dependence on freshwater systems to spawn and its predictable, seasonal mass spawning migrations into freshwater systems render it particularly vulnerable to overfishing. Habitat modification in estuaries is occurring in parts of its range and we infer that these events are contributing to population declines in parts of its range. Some authors have noted population declines in this species, which are currently unquantifiable. This high-value species occupies a shallow depth range (<20 m) and undergoes mass-spawning migrations to freshwater systems, factors which render it particularly vulnerable to increasing anthropogenic pressures on coastal areas as well as to overfishing. It is inferred that this species is dependent on fisheries management, such as off-fishing seasons, restrictions on minimum body size, support for stock enhancement programs, improvements to fishing grounds, protected areas, and the increasing reliance on species-specific aquaculture to meet increasing consumer demand which can not be met by wild stocks alone. Takifugu ocellatus is conservation dependent and is therefore assessed as Near Threatened. Due to the economic importance of the Takifugu genus, and the prevalence of taxonomic uncertainty within this group, we recommend further taxonomic studies utilizing both molecular and morphological methods in addition to habitat and population monitoring.
assessor: Hardy, G., Leis, J.L., Liu, M., Jing, L. & Matsuura, K.

rationale: This is a widespread species that grows in tropical and subtropical regions. It occurs in a wide variety of freshwater habitats including ponds, lakesides, pools, and ditches. Although there is no detailed information on this species global population, it covers a wide geographic range and it is common in freshwater habitats. No major threats have been reported. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Bhat, G.K., Rao, M.L.V., Dahanukar, N. & Molur, S.

rationale: Takifugu obscurus is known from the Yellow Sea, East China Sea and South China Sea to the Korean Peninsula. It is found in rivers in China. It is found at depths ranging from one to at least 20 m. This is a euryhaline species which lives in the bottom layer of inshore and inland waters. Spawning occurs in estuaries, and this species is known to migrate into freshwater to spawn. It is a commercial species which is considered highly-valued, however there is little information available to characterize the fishery. This species has been bred in captivity, and it is unclear whether or not this effort has been for the purposes of stock enhancement. There is little species-specific population information available. This species' dependence on freshwater systems to spawn and its predictable, seasonal mass spawning migrations into freshwater systems render it particularly vulnerable to overfishing. Seasonal fishing prohibitions and the presence of both fresh and marine water preserves in parts of its range may offer this species some protection. Takifugu obscurus is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Hardy, G., Matsuura, K., Shao, K., Jing, L., Leis, J.L. & Liu, M.

rationale:
Global

Pagellus bellottii is widespread and is one of the most abundant sparid species on the West African coast. It is a significant component of the multi-species coastal demersal fisheries in the Eastern Central Atlantic. There have been significant declines in biomass reported from Senegal and Ghana, and the stock is considered to be overexploited off the Cape Coast of Ghana. The Eastern Central Atlantic contributes the highest percentage of global landings reported to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) from 1950-2011; an overall increasing trend in landings is reported for Pagellus bellottii. Despite this increasing trend in global capture production, significant changes in biomass and trophic structure have been reported in the Senegal and Guinea ecosystems, where this species has undergone pronounced declines of up to 80-90%. We recommend close and continued monitoring of the populations of this species in West Africa; more recent stock assessments are also needed to better assess the status of the stock in the region. Given that this species is widely distributed in the Eastern Atlantic, from the Straits of Gibraltar to Angola, around the Canary Islands, and the southwestern Mediterranean; inhabits a wide depth range (up to 250 m); is found in relatively deeper waters (schools found in the upper 100 m); globally, it is not at a high risk of extinction in the near future and is listed as Least Concern.

Europe 

In Europe, this species is widespread and is one of the most abundant sparid species on the west African coast. However, in the European region it is only fished in The Canary Islands where it is a non-targeted species; elsewhere in the EU zone it is largely a vagrant. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: The taxonomic name was changed to Diplodus capensis from Diplodus sargus capensis in 2004 (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Two disjunct populations exist, one along the eastern seaboard of South Africa from Cape Point to southern Mozambique (Smith and Heemstra 1991, Mann 1992) and another from Namibia to southern Angola (Richardson 2010). These two populations may represent two separate species (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004, Richardson 2010). This evaluation dealt with D. capensis sensu strictu (distributed from False Bay to southern Mozambique).
rationale: Diplodus capensis is abundant along the southeastern seaboard of South Africa. This species is a major component of recreational and subsistence shore-based fisheries in the region and is prohibited in the commercial fishery (a "no sale" species). Diplodus capensis appears to have been able to sustain increasing fishing pressure with the aid of no-take MPAs in the area and species specific fishery regulations. Diplodus capensis exhibits early age and small size at maturity and an adaptable mode of reproduction which are likely to have facilitated the effective conservation efforts. However, D. capensis also exhibits life history traits that could render it susceptible to overexploitation including hermaphroditism, slow growth and long life span. The protandry exhibited by D. capensis makes females vulnerable to increased fishing pressure which in turn skews the sex ratio of the population, ultimately leading to a decline in overall population productivity by the reduction of fecundity and possibly recruitment. Since the females are larger in size they are also the limiting factor in regards to fecundity, thus reducing the number of large, fecund females can largely impede the fertility of a population. The spawning aggregations formed by D. capensis adults take place near the surface of the water and contribute to the vulnerability of this species as their spawning locations are predictable and easily targeted. Although a decline in population has not yet been observed, D. capensis should be closely monitored as this species is extremely important to recreational and subsistence fisheries. Improved regulation enforcement is recommended for this fishery as widespread non-compliance of minimum landing size may pose a threat to D. capensis. In addition to improved regulation enforcement, larger MPAs and a fisher awareness program are also recommended to aid in the conservation of D. capensis. Given that it is widespread and the populations appear to be stable, currently it is not at a high risk of extinction in the near future and is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Mann, B.Q., Buxton, C.D., Russell, B., Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E. & Sadovy, Y.

Diplodus capensis exhibits early age and small size at maturity and an adaptable mode of reproduction which are likely to have facilitated the effective conservation efforts. However, D. capensis also exhibits life history traits that could render it susceptible to overexploitation including hermaphroditism, slow growth and long life span. The protandry exhibited by D. capensis makes females vulnerable to increased fishing pressure which in turn skews the sex ratio of the population, ultimately leading to a decline in overall population productivity by the reduction of fecundity and possibly recruitment. Since the females are larger in size they are also the limiting factor in regards to fecundity, thus reducing the number of large, fecund females can largely impede the fertility of a population. The spawning aggregations formed by D. capensis adults take place near the surface of the water and contribute to the vulnerability of this species as their spawning locations are predictable and easily targeted. Although a decline in population has not yet been observed, D. capensis should be closely monitored as this species is extremely important to recreational and subsistence fisheries. Improved regulation enforcement is recommended for this fishery as widespread non-compliance of minimum landing size may pose a threat to D. capensis. In addition to improved regulation enforcement, larger MPAs and a fisher awareness program are also recommended to aid in the conservation of D. capensis. Given that it is widespread and the populations appear to be stable, currently it is not at a high risk of extinction in the near future and is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Mann, B.Q., Buxton, C.D., Russell, B., Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E. & Sadovy, Y.

rationale: Pagrus africanus is relatively widespread along the coast of West Africa from Senegal to Angola including Sao Tome and Cape Verde. It is a subthermocline species in Gabon waters and reaches maximum densities at depths between 70 m and 150 m. There are no data indicating population declines from fishing at present. There is a need for additional research regarding the biology and population of this species. Although there are no species specific conservation efforts in place for P. africanus, its distribution overlaps with marine reserves in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E. & Russell, B.

taxonomicnotes: This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of Pagellus bellottii. It is currently valid as Pagellus natalensis (Eschmeyer and Fricke 2009).
rationale: Pagellus natalensis is widespread and abundant throughout its range. It was previously recognized as a subspecies of Pagellus bellottii. Population information is limited for this species. Pagellus natalensis is caught as a trawl bycatch and targeted as a bait species in the party-boat fishery off Durban (South Africa) and contributes little to the shore angling fishery. There are no major threats known for the species and it is effectively protected in marine protected areas. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Mann, B.Q., Buxton, C.D., Russell, B., Pollard, D. & Carpenter, K.E.

taxonomicnotes: This species was previously confused with Acanthopagrus vagus in South Africa (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004, Iwatsuki and Heemstra 2010).
rationale: Acanthopagrus berda is widely distributed and may have suffered from local overfishing and/or habitat degradation in some areas but is still relatively abundant elsewhere. The distribution overlaps several marine protected areas where it is likely to receive some protection. Therefore, Acanthopagrus berda is listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Russell, B., Mann, B.Q., Buxton, C.D., Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E., Iwatsuki, Y., Liao, L. & Shao, K.

taxonomicnotes:
Diplodus cervinus was previously recognized as comprising three subspecies: Diplodus cervinus cervinus (NE Atlantic and Mediterranean), D. c. hottentotus (SE Atlantic: Angola, South Africa), and D. c. omanensis (Indian Ocean: Oman). Currently, three species are recognized: D. cervinus, D. hottentotus (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004) and D. omanensis (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Amir et al. 2013). Diplodus hottentotus is now believed to be an endemic species occurring from Cape Point to Kosi Bay in South Africa (Smith and Heemstra 1986, Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Diplodus hottentotus sensu strictu. However, the Diplodus cervinus complex is in need of taxonomic review (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).

The species D. hottentotus is the same species in southern Angola as it is along the eastern seaboard of southern Africa. However, as with D. capensis, these populations have been separated for ~ two million years by the Benguela Current so can be treated as separate populations for management purposes (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Winkler 2013).
rationale: The zebra (Diplodus hottentotus) occurs from False Bay to southern Mozambique to depths of 120 m. There is an isolated subpopulation in Angola. Currently, no major threats or population declines have been identified for this species. However, D. hottentotus is a slow growing, and late maturing species that exhibits high residency which make it susceptible to possible overexploitation. This species is targeted by subsistence and recreational fishers but has been decommercialized (no sale). Diplodus hottentotus is also afforded some protection by the no-take MPAs along the South African coast. It is listed at Least Concern.
assessor: Mann, B.Q., Buxton, C.D., Russell, B., Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E. & Sadovy, Y.

taxonomicnotes: Diplodus cervinus was previously recognized as comprising three subspecies: Diplodus cervinus cervinus (NE Atlantic and Mediterranean), D. c. hottentotus (SE Atlantic: Angola, South Africa), and D. c. omanensis (Indian Ocean: Oman). Currently, three species are recognized: D. cervinus, D. hottentotus (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004) and D. omanensis (Bauchot and Bianchi 1984, Amir et al. 2013). However, the Diplodus cervinus complex is in need of taxonomic review (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2014).
rationale: Diplodus omanensis is only known from to southern Oman and western Pakistan but there are no apparent threats at the present time. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Iwatsuki, Y., Russell, B., Pollard, D., Mann, B.Q., Carpenter, K.E. & Buxton, C.D.

taxonomicnotes: Diplodus sargus as presently recognized is an assemblage of genetically closely related species whose current taxonomic assignments of species and subspecies are somewhat inconsistent and require further work (Summerer et al. 2001). Pending more detailed population genetic work, the six subspecies of D. sargus, are retained in individual subspecies accounts but are not separated in the parents species account.
rationale: Diplodus sargus ssp. cadenati is relatively widespread along the West African coast and is common in parts of its range. It inhabits rocky bottoms down to depths of 150 m. It is susceptible to exploitation but there is no evidence of overfishing at the present time. It is found in marine protected areas in parts of its range and is therefore listed Least Concern.
assessor: Carpenter, K.E., Russell, B. & Pollard, D.

taxonomicnotes:
The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

Most often, Spicara flexuosa has been confused with S. maena in identifications, and they are typically lumped in fisheries statistics and in markets. Spicara flexuosa is currently considered a synonym of S. maena (Pollard and Pichot 1972, Heemstra 1990, Bilecenoglu et al. 2002, Minos et al. 2012), although genetic studies using the mtDNA 16S rRNA gene are inconclusive. Recent genetic work by Imsiridou et al. (2011) indicates that there is a clear discrimination between the two species, and Minos et al. (2012) distinguished the two based on morphological differences.

However, Turan (2011) found genetic divergence to be only 0.005 and previous work by Arculeo et al. (1996) using protein electrophoresis found no discriminating genetic markers. Pending further taxonomic studies, we here continue to regard S. flexuosa as a synonym of S. maena (Pichot and Pollard 1970, Pollard and Pichot 1971, Pollard and Pichot 1972).
rationale:
Global

Spicara maena is occurs in the eastern Atlantic Ocean, also occurring throughout the Mediterranean and part of the Black Sea. This species is of minor commercial importance but indications of substantial population declines have not been observed. It is therefore listed globally as Least Concern. However, because of increased landings of this species, we recommend continued monitoring of its population status and harvest levels.


Europe

In Europe, this species is widespread and can be locally abundant. It is of minor commercial importance and no major threats have been identified. It is therefore listed regionally as Least Concern.
assessor: Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E. & Russell, B.

taxonomicnotes:
The family Centracanthidae will soon be subsumed under the family Sparidae, because the centracanthid fishes are highly polyphyletic with sparid fishes (Chiba et al. 2009, Hanel and Tsigenopoulos 2011, Santini et al. 2014).

Most often, Spicara flexuosa has been confused with S. maena in identifications, and they are typically lumped in fisheries statistics and in markets. Spicara flexuosa is currently considered a synonym of S. maena (Pollard and Pichot 1972, Heemstra 1990, Bilecenoglu et al. 2002, Minos et al. 2012), although genetic studies using the mtDNA 16S rRNA gene are inconclusive. Recent genetic work by Imsiridou et al. (2011) indicates that there is a clear discrimination between the two species, and Minos et al. (2012) distinguished the two based on morphological differences.

However, Turan (2011) found genetic divergence to be only 0.005 and previous work by Arculeo et al. (1996) using protein electrophoresis found no discriminating genetic markers. Pending further taxonomic studies, we here continue to regard S. flexuosa as a synonym of S. maena (Pichot and Pollard 1970, Pollard and Pichot 1971, Pollard and Pichot 1972).
rationale:
Global

Spicara maena is occurs in the eastern Atlantic Ocean, also occurring throughout the Mediterranean and part of the Black Sea. This species is of minor commercial importance but indications of substantial population declines have not been observed. It is therefore listed globally as Least Concern. However, because of increased landings of this species, we recommend continued monitoring of its population status and harvest levels.


Europe

In Europe, this species is widespread and can be locally abundant. It is of minor commercial importance and no major threats have been identified. It is therefore listed regionally as Least Concern.
assessor: Pollard, D., Carpenter, K.E. & Russell, B.

taxonomicnotes: The Pacific (Thunnus orientalis) and Atlantic (Thunnus thynnus) Bluefin populations are now recognized as separate species (Collette 1999). Thunnus saliens Jordan & Evermann 1926 is a junior synonym of T. orientalis.
rationale: Thunnus orientalis, known commonly as the Pacific Bluefin Tuna, is a highly commercial and valuable species. Based on estimates of spawning stock biomass (SSB) it is estimated that this species’ population has declined between 19–33% over the past 22 years (or three generation lengths, using an estimated 7.4 year generation length). Based on several fisheries reference points, the most recent stock assessment concludes that overfishing is occurring and the stock is overfished (ISC 2014). The latest fisheries stock assessment estimates that the SSB in 2012 was approximately 4% of the stock’s estimated unfished SSB levels. Moreover, the average recruitment in the last five years may also be below the historical average level of recruitment, with the recruitment level in 2012 being the 8th lowest in 61 years. Additionally, there is concern that optimistically high levels of adult natural mortality and assumptions of no relationship between recruitment and biomass used in the most recent stock assessment may have contributed to an overly optimistic stock outlook. Furthermore, the current fishery may be dependent on one strong cohort, which will likely disappear given the targeting of juveniles in the Western Pacific (Maunder et al. 2014). For these reasons, this species is listed as Vulnerable under Criterion A2bd. Based on the current WCPFC and IATTC management and conservation measures, it is unlikely that the status of the stock will improve if low recruitment continues, therefore, more effective management measures to reduce fishing mortality and increase SSB are needed.
assessor: Collette, B., Fox, W., Juan Jorda, M., Nelson, R., Pollard, D., Suzuki, N. & Teo, S.

taxonomicnotes: A. mwanzae was previously regarded as a subspecies of A. planiceps Peters, 1862 (Spawls et al. 2002).
rationale: Agama mwanzae has been assessed as Least Concern due to its large distribution and tolerance of anthropogenic environments. No specific threats have been reported and this species is not undegoing significant population declines.
assessor: Menegon, M., Spawls, S., Wagner, P. & Beraduccii, J.

taxonomicnotes: A. mwanzae was previously regarded as a subspecies of A. planiceps Peters, 1862 (Spawls et al. 2002).
rationale: Agama mwanzae has been assessed as Least Concern due to its large distribution and tolerance of anthropogenic environments. No specific threats have been reported and this species is not undegoing significant population declines.
assessor: Menegon, M., Spawls, S., Wagner, P. & Beraduccii, J.

taxonomicnotes: A. mwanzae was previously regarded as a subspecies of A. planiceps Peters, 1862 (Spawls et al. 2002).
rationale: Agama mwanzae has been assessed as Least Concern due to its large distribution and tolerance of anthropogenic environments. No specific threats have been reported and this species is not undegoing significant population declines.
assessor: Menegon, M., Spawls, S., Wagner, P. & Beraduccii, J.

taxonomicnotes: Puntius punctatus was described by Day (1865) from the erstwhile princely state of Cochin , Kerala, India. Day (1889) later changed the generic status of the fish to Barbus. Hora, Misra and Malik (1939) synonymized Puntius punctatus to a more widely distributed species Puntius ticto. However, Silas (1939) considered P. punctatus as a valid subspecies P. ticto punctatus. Even though Talwar and Jhingran (1991) and Jayaram (1991, 1999) considered Puntius punctatus as a synonym of Puntius ticto; Menon (1999) and Devi et al. (2007) have considered Puntius punctatus as a valid species.
rationale: Puntius punctatus is assessed as Least Concerned solely based on the fact that the inferred extent of occurrence for this species is more than any threatened category. Nevertheless, it is essential to note that the species is very rare and the area in which the species is found is threatened by urbanization, tourism, invasive fish species and agricultural pollution.
evaluator: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Molur, S.

rationale:
Global Assessment: This is a widespread shallow-water species that is common with no known threats and occurs in Marine Protected Areas. It is considered Least Concern.

The Persian Gulf Regional Assessment: Oceanographic data suggests that a rescue effect through the Strait of Hormuz is negligible. It is not known whether or not this species is directly affected by this coastal development throughout the Persian Gulf. Given this species' habitat preferences, it's likely it is impacted negatively in some parts of the region. However, current data does not suggest a decline in population numbers (Coles and Tarr 1990). Therefore, Omobranchus punctatus is listed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Buchanan, J., Strongin, K., Polidoro, B. & Carpenter, K.E.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Trioceros schoutedeni in Tilbury and Tolley (2009). This species overlaps in distribution with T. rudis and is morphologically similar, resulting in confusion between the two species. Where the two species co-occur, it is not possible to determine which records belong to T. schoutedeni and which to T. rudis. It differs from T. rudis mainly on the basis of a much reduced gular, and ventral crest.
rationale: The habitat preference of this species is not known, and therefore the threats are not understood. There is a lack of information to assess this species and it is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
assessor: Tolley, K., Plumptre, A. & Menegon, M.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Kinyongia vosseleri in Mariaux et al. (2008).
rationale: This species is listed as Endangered on the basis that it has an Extent of Occurrence of approximately 800 km2, with less than 300 km2 of suitable forest remaining within this range. It occurs as a severely fragmented population due to its reliance on highly fragmented forest habitat, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of this habitat due to the ongoing impacts of timber removal, resource utilization, encroachment and transformation for agriculture. Although it is sometimes observed outside the primary forest, these observations are close to forested areas and on vegetation that is thick and structurally complex. It does not tolerate extremely altered habitats.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Kinyongia uluguruensis in Mariaux et al. (2008).
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because although it has a restricted distribution, the forested habitat where it occurs is formally protected, is under minimal disturbance, and the population is not considered severely fragmented.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Trioceros schubotzi in Tilbury and Tolley (2009).
rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened (nearly meeting VU D2) because it has a small distribution consisting of one location, and although it occurs entirely within a National Park there is the potential threat for an increase in fire frequency due to human activities. Frequent fires would prevent the population from recovering adequately, which would negatively impact the species. The small distribution also means that the population would lack an adequate buffer in terms of both population size and available habitat, when fires are large. There are no other tangible threats, due to the high elevation, so the species is presently not impacted by anthropogenic activities such as habitat loss and degradation.

taxonomicnotes:
Trioceros sternfeldi  was described by Rand (1963) in his re-assessment if the Trioceros bitaeniatus complex (Rand 1963). He designated specimens from Mt. Meru and Mt. Kilimanjaro to the new subspecies Chamaeleo rudis sternfeldi. Some authors have accepted the subspecific designation (Mertens 1966), but others regarded the subspecies as invalid (Broadley and Howell 1991, Klaver and Böhme 1997, Spawls and Rotich 1997, Spawls et al. 2002). Tricoeros sternfeldi is now regarded as a full species by most authors (Necas 1999, Tilbury 2010, Stipala 2014, Spawls et al. 2014). However, the population of “T. sternfeldi” from Mount Hanang (sensu Tilbury 2010) was recently described as T. hanangensis (Krause and Böhme 2010) which restricts the distribution of T. sternfeldi to Kilimanjaro, Mt. Meru and the Ngorongoro highlands. In addition, Stipala (unpub. data 2013) suggests that the T. sternfeldi population from Ngorongoro is more closely related to T. hanangensis than to T. sternfeldi. Furthermore, the taxonomic status of recently discovered T. cf. sternfeldi populations in montane localities in Kenya (i.e. Samburu/Karsia Hills, Loita Hills) needs to be confirmed with additional research, but Stipala (2014) suggests they are genetically distinct from T. sternfeldi. 

Unassigned records tentatively referred to Trioceros rudis incertae sedis (Tilbury 2010) known from Tanzania and Kenya may belong to this taxon. Molecular work by Townsend and Larson (2002) confirmed the genetic distinctiveness of the Tanzanian ‘rudis’ from populations in the Albertine Rift and subsequent studies have re-enforced those conclusions with more detailed molecular analyses (Tolley and Tilbury 2009, Krause and Boehme 2010). In turn, many of the localities from the Albertine Rift may not represent T. rudis sensu stricto, so the Tanzanian/Albertine Rift comparison may not even refer to T. rudis but to several undescribed taxa. It is clear that the T. rudis/sternfeldi complex is in need of a taxonomic assessment that is based on comprehensive sampling from multiple localities, within a phylogenetic framework.
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, it has an estimated extent of occurrence of ca. 27,000 km<sup>2</sup>, and it occurs in several protected areas. It can be common in disturbed habitats, and is not thought to be subject to major threats.
assessor: Tolley, K., Plumptre, A. & Menegon, M.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Kinyongia excubitor in Tilbury et al. (2006, 2007).
rationale: This species has an Area of Occupancy of 1,250 km<sup>2</sup> and because of heavy fragmentation and extensive habitat destruction it is estimated that probably up to about 80% of the original population has been lost (although not sufficiently rapidly or recently to trigger a listing under Criterion A), and there is a continuing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat. Because it does not occur in the transformed landscapes, and is limited to forest fragments, the population is considered severely fragmented. It is therefore listed as VU B1ab(i,ii,iii)+2ab(i,ii,iii).

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Kinyongia multituberculata in Mariaux et al. (2008) and Tilbury (2010).
rationale: This species is listed as Endangered applying Criteria B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii) because it occurs as a severely fragmented population restricted to highly fragmented forest patches and their immediate surroundings, a habitat that is undergoing a continuing decline in both extent and quality due to the impacts of timber removal,  resource utilization, and encroachment and transformation for agriculture.  This species is also one of the most heavily exported from East Africa  for the pet trade. It is not clear whether current levels of export are sustainable, and research is needed to determine whether offtake is contributing to suspected population declines. Although it is observed in transformed landscapes, these observations are close to forested areas and on vegetation that is thick and structurally complex, and it will not tolerance heavy disturbance.
assessor: Tolley, K., Menegon, M. & Plumptre, A.

taxonomicnotes: Kaestlea palnica was described by Boettger in 1892 as Lygosoma (Leiolopisma) travancoricum var. palnica based on specimens collected from Kodaikanal, Palni Hills, Tamil Nadu. Smith (1935) accorded this form specific status. Species now assigned to Kaestlea have been assigned to various genera and until recently were placed in the genus Scincella. Eremchenko and Das (2004) erected the new genus Kaestlea to accommodate peninsular Indian species.
rationale: Kaestlea palnica  is a restricted range species. It is presently known only from Kodaikanal and Palni Hills in Tamil Nadu. It has not been reported since its type description. Nothing is known about the ecology and population status of this species, although it has been recorded from shola forest and is presumed to be confined to this habitat. It is listed as Data Deficient on the basis that nothing is known of its distribution and therefore of either its distributional extent or the extent of its exposure to threats, however, forest habitat at the historically-known sites is under ongoing pressure from infrastructure development to support tourism.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Roy, A.D., Pal, S., Sondhi, S. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: Uropeltis myhendrae was described as Silybura nilgherriensis var. myhendrae by Beddome in 1886 based on type series collected from the Myhendra mountain (=Mahendragiri), Tirunelvelli district, Tamil Nadu, India  (Beddome 1886, Smith 1943). Boulenger (1890) upgraded myhendrae to specific level.
rationale: Uropeltis myhendrae is known only from two localities and there is no information on its population status, ecology or threats. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
assessor: Srinivasulu, B., Srinivasulu, C., Ganesan, S.R. & Vijayakumar, S.P.
evaluator: Auliya, M., Bowles, P., Ramesh, M., Madala, M., Prabhu, M., Sreekar, R. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: Eublepharis fuscus was described as a subspecies of Eublepharis macularius Blyth, 1854 by Börner (1981) from 60 km north of Bombay (presently Mumbai). However, this species is a distinct form and allopatric to Eublepharis macularius, hence has been elevated to species status (Das 1997). The taxa belonging to the genus Eublepharis are included under Family Eublepharidae since past 20 years (A.M. Bauer pers. comm. 09 May 2011).
rationale: Eublepharis fuscus is widely distributed in western India and may occur in southeastern Pakistan. Although there are several threats identified affecting the species in Maharashtra and Gujarat with a perceived decline in population, it is represented in several protected areas.  It is assessed as Least Concern, but it is recommended that specific impacts of threats to the species be assessed through field surveys.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Thakur, S., Vyas, R., Bauer, A., Roy, A.D., Murthy, B.H.C.K., Agarwal, I., Sondhi, S., Pal, S. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: Ahaetulla pulverulenta was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in 1854 as Dryinus pulverulentus based on specimen from unknown locality (Smith 1943). Type locality restricted to "Ceylan" (=Sri Lanka) by David and Dubois (2005) after the rediscovery of the holotype (MNHN 7565 coll. L.T. Leschenault) discovered in the Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, Paris.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its reasonably wide distribution, its occurrence in a number of protected areas, and because no threats have been identified to this somewhat adaptable snake.
assessor: Srinivasulu, C., Srinivasulu, B., Deepak, V., Achyuthan, N.S. & Vyas, R.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Das, A., Mohapatra, P., Shankar, G., Kulkarni, N.U., Thakur, S., Sawant, N.S., Aengals, A., Jose, J. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: Ahaetulla pulverulenta was described by Duméril, Bibron and Duméril in 1854 as Dryinus pulverulentus based on specimen from unknown locality (Smith 1943). Type locality restricted to "Ceylan" (=Sri Lanka) by David and Dubois (2005) after the rediscovery of the holotype (MNHN 7565 coll. L.T. Leschenault) discovered in the Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, Paris.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its reasonably wide distribution, its occurrence in a number of protected areas, and because no threats have been identified to this somewhat adaptable snake.
assessor: Srinivasulu, C., Srinivasulu, B., Deepak, V., Achyuthan, N.S. & Vyas, R.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Das, A., Mohapatra, P., Shankar, G., Kulkarni, N.U., Thakur, S., Sawant, N.S., Aengals, A., Jose, J. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: Calliophis nigrescens was described by Günther in 1862 based on type specimen from India (Smith 1943). The exact location of the type locality is unknown, and could be restricted to southern Western Ghats.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it is seldom recorded, it has a relatively wide distribution and is tolerant of a degree of habitat modification.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Vyas, R., Das, A., Mohapatra, P., Achyuthan, N.S., Kulkarni, N.U., Sawant, N.S., Jose, J., Aengals, A., Thakur, S. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: The taxonomic status of records from Tsaratanana, referred to Calumma cf. guillaumeti by Raxworthy et al. (2008), is in need of clarification (C. Raxworthy pers. comm. June 2011).
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although it has an extent of occurrence of 6,449 km², there is a continuing decline in area and quality of habitat only at the lower elevational limit of its range, and the population is not likely to be severely fragmented. With limited immediate threats, it is difficult to define any of the massifs in terms of the number of locations they represent. This situation should be monitored, as upslope displacement of agricultural activities would require reassessment of this species and would probably warrant listing it as at least Near Threatened, and possibly in a threatened category.
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Anjeriniaina, M., Brady, L., Glaw, F., Griffiths, R.A., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

taxonomicnotes: The taxonomy of Calumma marojezense is in need of revision.
rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened based on nearly qualifying for listing under the B criterion. Specifically, the species has an extent of occurrence of 9,500 km², it is known from four locations and may genuinely occur at fewer than ten defined by the threats to its forest habitat, but although there is currently a continuing decline in area and quality of habitat within its range, it is not expected to occur as a severely fragmented population.
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Anjeriniaina, M., Brady, L., Glaw, F., Griffiths, R.A., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

taxonomicnotes: This chameleon was formerly considered a subspecies of C. gastrotaenia, but was elevated to species status by Böhme (1997). Individuals from Andohahela in the southeast require additional study to verify their taxonomic status (Andreone et al. 2001, Glaw and Vences 2007).
rationale: Listed as Endangered as the species has a small range in southwestern Madagascar, its known extent of occurrence being only 1,220 km²<sup></sup>, it occurs as a severely fragmented population, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to agricultural activities and logging.
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Anjeriniaina, M., Glaw, F., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

taxonomicnotes: Although considered a subspecies of C. oshaughnessyi in the past, Glaw and Vences (2007) gave it specific status because of its distinctness, and this was accepted by Andreone et al. (2009). A specimen from Tsaratanana is tentatively assigned to this species, however its taxonomy is in need of clarification (M. Vences pers. comm. June 2011) and Tsaratanana is not considered part of this chameleon's range in this assessment.
rationale: Listed as Near Threatened based on the species nearly qualifying for listing as Vulnerable under D2. The species is confined to a single site, Montagne d'Ambre, with a plausible future potential threat that could impact the species. If the threat became operational, the species would not likely qualify for listing as Critically Endangered; however, it would certainly immediately be eligible for listing as Endangered since its range is only 385 km², it would occur at a single location (where the threat is habitat loss from agricultural activities and logging) and there would be a continuing decline in the quality and area of habitat (qualifying the species for the criteria B1ab(iii)).
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Anjeriniaina, M., Glaw, F., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

taxonomicnotes: Calumma hilleniusi has variously been considered either a full species or a subspecies of C. brevicorne (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 2006). The identity of southern subpopulations currently assigned to this species requires verification (Vences et al. 2002).
rationale: Listed as Endangered as the chameleon's extent of occurrence is only 820 km²<sup></sup> in an area of Madagascar where the habitat is undergoing a continuing decline due mainly to logging, and the population is severely fragmented.
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Andriantsimanarilafy, R.A., Anjeriniaina, M., Brady, L., Glaw, F., Griffiths, R.A., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

taxonomicnotes: Records of this species from Ambohijanahary are attributable to Furcifer willsii (F. Glaw pers. comm. January 2011). Records from Parc National Tsingy de Bemaraha may represent this taxon,. F. willsii, or an undescribed form; due to uncertainty about the correct assignment of these records the Bemaraha records are not included in the assessments for either F. petteri or F. wilsii.
rationale: Listed as Vulnerable as the species has a narrow range in northern Madagascar (around 11,000 km²<sup></sup>), where remaining forest habitat continues to decline in extent and quality due to ongoing agricultural activities and logging, and it is thought to occur as a severely fragmented population.
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Anjeriniaina, M., Brady, L., Glaw, F., Griffiths, R.A., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

rationale: Epipactis palustris is widespread and often found in dense colonies. Overall, the populations are declining, but the existing threats are unlikely to cause the populations to decline severely in the near future. Therefore, Epipactis palustris is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Recent research has shown genetic and morphometric divergence between populations in the north and south of Grande Terre suggesting that at least two or more cryptic taxa may be included within Caledoniscincus atropunctatus sensu Roux 1913.
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because it is widespread and abundant, and it is present in many protected areas.

Emoia loyaltiensis is listed as Vulnerable because of the small extent of occurrence and area of occupancy and the ongoing threats that are contributing to a decline in the area of occupancy and population size.

taxonomicnotes: The taxonomy of Bradypodion transvaalense is unclear, molecular studies are now underway (K. Tolley pers. comm. 2010).
rationale: Bradypodion transvaalense has been assessed as Least Concern owing to its wide distribution and its tolerance of a broad range of habitats, including anthropogenic environments. However, taxonomic uncertainty still exists within this species and therefore further research should be carried out to clarify the taxonomy, and reassessment of conservation status may be required depending on the outcome of this research.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

taxonomicnotes: This species was originally named as a distinct species before being reduced to the subspecies, Trioceros bitaeniatus Fischer, 1884 by Werner (1911). Rand (1963) revised the complicated systematics of the bitaeniatus group and elevated T. hoehnelii to a full species once again, while several other taxa from the bitaeniatus group became junior synonyms under T. hoehnelii (Chamaeleon leikipiensis Steindachner 1891, Chamaeleon bitaeniatus bergeri Sternfeld 1912, Chamaeleon bitaeniatus alteelgonis Loveridge 1935).  At present T. hoehnelii (Steindachner, 1891) is considered monotypic (Klaver and Bohme 1986, Spawls et al. 2004, Tilbury 2010) although some authors have recognised T. hoehnelii altaeelgonis as a valid taxon (Mertens 1966, Necas 1999). In addition, there are several areas of potential disjunction in the distribution of this species, which could lead to isolation of populations. The Mt. Elgon population is apparently genetically distinct, but the level of this divergence has not been established (Stipala 2014). Therefore, the species should be investigated in a phylogenetic context.
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern due to its large extent of occurrence, abundance, and tolerance of habitat modification.

taxonomicnotes: There is some uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of the presumed Southern Highlands population of this species. It was originally considered a sub-species (Trioceros laterispinis brookesiaformis) but was later synonymised (Böhme 1987). There is only one specimen from the Southern Highlands, and its actual collection locality (Kibau Iyayi) is not certain. The existence of this population significantly affects this species' extent of occurrence and both its occurrence in this area and taxonomic status needs to be verified.
rationale: Trioceros laterispinis is listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has an area of occupancy of 538 km2, and within this, the species occurs as a severely fragmented population. There is a continuing decline in the quality of its forest habitat due to degradation of forest, and ongoing declines in area of occupancy are inferred due to encroachment.

taxonomicnotes: Dendrelaphis grandoculis was described by Boulenger in 1890 as Dendrophis grandoculis based on specimens collected from Thirunelvelli Hills and Coonoor Ghats, Tamil Nadu, India (Smith 1943).
rationale: Dendrelaphis grandoculis is listed as Least Concern as this species is adaptable and believed to occur throughout an area of around 25,000 km2. Although, the quality of forest habitat is declining throughout its range, such threats are currently thought to be somewhat localized and the species is somewhat tolerant of disturbance. Nevertheless, studies are recommended to clarify the extent to which this species can tolerate habitat modification.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Vijayakumar, S.P., Deepak, V. & Molur, S.

rationale: Philodryas varia has been assessed as Least Concern, because it has a large distribution and is not being impacted by any major threats or thought to undergo population declines.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

rationale: Philodryas varia has been assessed as Least Concern, because it has a large distribution and is not being impacted by any major threats or thought to undergo population declines.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
assessor: Hamilton, A., Allison, A. & Tallowin, O.

taxonomicnotes: This species was treated for a time as a subspecies of Hemiphyllodactylus typus until 1999 when Bauer and Das showed it to be a distinct species.
rationale: Hemiphyllodactylus aurantiacus is a widespread species with an  extent of occurrence estimated to be greater than 20,000 km2, and may have a larger range than is presently known. It has been assessed as Least Concern. Habitat loss and degradation are likely threats within this species' range, however, this gecko is reported to occur in anthropogenic environments and due to its wide range impacts may be localized.
evaluator: Bowles, P., Bauer, A., Roy, A.D., Murthy, B.H.C.K., Agarwal, I., Sondhi, S., Pal, S. & Molur, S.

rationale: Anolis ahli is listed as Endangered because its estimated extent of occurrence approximates to around 600 km2, there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and given the wide-spread nature of the threat of deforestation and the fact that known museum localities are very close to each other, it is likely that all individuals are found in five or fewer locations. The establishment and management of new protected areas are needed to ensure this species' survival. Further research and monitoring of Anolis ahli is required to ensure a decline in abundance triggers a more severe threat category.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M.

rationale: Anolis armouri has been listed as Near Threatened, due to its limited extent of occurrence of less than 5,000 km2 and the fact that it is locally threatened with habitat loss due to deforestation. However, the species tolerates a number of habitats and occurs in more than ten locations, so that it is unlikely to decline fast enough to warrant a threatened category. Its range also coincides with protected areas, probably providing small safeguards. Further research and monitoring is needed to ensure a threatened category will be triggered, if threats intensify.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M.

rationale: Anolis clivicola has been assessed as Least Concern because, although it is only found in three locations, threats in these areas are thought to have ceased so that its population is unlikely to be declining at present. Furthermore, the species is considered abundant where found and some areas in which it occurs coincide with protected areas that have not shown a continuing decline in quality. However, the species has a small extent of occurrence so that it should be monitored to ensure it does not trigger a threat category in the future.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M.

taxonomicnotes: Anolis cristifer was originally considered to be a subspecies of A. pentaprion, based on a single male specimen the characteristics of which appeared to fall within the variations shown by southern populations of A. pentaprion (Smith 1968). It was elevated to species status based on distinct differences in scalation by Köhler and Acevedo (2004) and Köhler (2008). Since this species has not received much research attention, the taxonomy of it may still need to be resolved.
rationale: Anolis cristifer has been assessed as Data Deficient. This species' extent of occurrence has been estimated as approximately 13,100 km2 which would qualify the species for a VU assessment under criterion B1. Potential threats may occur within its range in the form of habitat destruction for agricultural development. However, the species has not received much research attention, so that while the species' range may coincide with protected areas, it is unknown what effects habitat destruction has on the populations. Research is needed to bridge this knowledge gap and establish the species' habitat requirements as well as assess the effects of habitat loss on the population.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M.

taxonomicnotes: This species was recognized as a full species from the mtDNA and allozyme data presented by Schneider et al. (2001), as well as the biogeographical and morphological differences.
rationale: This species has been assessed as Vulnerable as it is restricted to one small island. Although no information is available regarding current threats to this species, it is obvious from its past extinctions from other islands that they do exist. Therefore more research and monitoring should be conducted to ensure that this species does not decline, triggering assignment to a higher threat category.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M.

rationale: Bothrops oligolepis has been assessed as Least Concern owing to its wide distribution in Peru and northern Bolivia. Further research is required into the threats that this species may face. At present, it is unlikely to be undergoing a significant population decline and is not considered as threatened.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

rationale: Bothrops oligolepis has been assessed as Least Concern owing to its wide distribution in Peru and northern Bolivia. Further research is required into the threats that this species may face. At present, it is unlikely to be undergoing a significant population decline and is not considered as threatened.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

rationale: Scelotes mossambicus has been assessed as Least Concern owing to its ability to adapt to disturbed habitats. No specific threats have been reported and it is unlikely to be undergoing significant population declines.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

rationale: Scelotes mossambicus has been assessed as Least Concern owing to its ability to adapt to disturbed habitats. No specific threats have been reported and it is unlikely to be undergoing significant population declines.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M. (Sampled Red List Index Coordinating Team)

rationale: Anolis spectrum has been assessed as Near Threatened.  This species has a restricted range with an extent of occurence less than 20,000 km2, but this is not considered severely fragmented and coincides with a number of protected areas. Further research and monitoring is needed to ensure that a higher threat category is appropriately assigned if necessary due to significant population declines.
evaluator: Böhm, M., Collen, B. & Ram, M.

rationale: Gibbonsia montereyensis is widely distributed in the Eastern Tropical Pacific. It is common on inshore rocky areas in algae. There are no major threats known and its distribution overlaps with marine protected areas in parts of its range. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Hastings, P.A., Clements, K.D., Holleman, W. & Williams, J.T.
evaluator: Comeros-Raynal, M., Polidoro, B. & Carpenter, K.E.

rationale: This subspecies is restricted to three locations, the Agnébi, San Pedro and Banco basins in Côte d’Ivoire. The EOO is less than 20,000 km² and the AOO is less than 2,000 km². There is no information on any major threats to the subspecies. But due to its restricted range and potential threat from deforestation and agriculture developments the subspecies is assessed as Vulnerable.
evaluator: Entsua-Mensah, M., Darwall, W. & Smith, K.

taxonomicnotes: This species has a disjunct distribution that may involve two species, one distributed in the Gulf of California and the other in southern Mexico.
rationale: This species is relatively widespread in the Eastern Pacific, and is common throughout its range. There are no known major threats to this species, and no current indication of population decline. It is listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Bessudo, S., Dominici-Arosemena, A., Espinosa, H. & Hastings, P.
evaluator: Carpenter, K., Polidoro, B. & Livingstone, S. (Global Marine Species Assessment Team)

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern. There are no known threats.
assessor: Smith-Vaniz,B., Collette, B., Bussing, W., Guzman-Mora, A.G. & Salas, E.
evaluator: Carpenter, K., Polidoro, B. & Livingstone, S. (Global Marine Species Assessment Team)

taxonomicnotes: In his revision of the Paleartic unionids, Haas (1940) considered the three Moroccan species described by Pallary (1918, 1923 and 1928) to belong to a single subspecies of the European Psilunio auricularius (Spengler, 1792 ), namely P. auricularius marocanus. Some authors (Van Damme 1984; Ghamizi 1998) retained the Moroccan form as distinctive while others (Mandahl-Barth 1988; Daget, 1998) did not. Recent molecular and conchiological investigation show that this species is a separate species, differing from the European species e.g., by its smaller size, nearly black outer test and differences in the hinge.
rationale:
This species is restricted to one location in the Oued Derna (a very small population with a range of about 100 m, sampled in 2006) and two locations in the Oued Beth (population size assumed small, range 300 m, sampled in 1990s). There has been a massive population reduction (greater than 80%) in the last 100 years (and species generation time 50-100 years), meaning it qualifies as Critically Endangered.

The estimated remaining population size is fewer than 250 individuals with an estimated continuing decline of more than 25% in 1 generation. The decrease in the past has been alarming. The species depends for its propagation on a host fish species presently unknown. Most likely this is a salmonid or a blenny. The dramatic reduction of the European Pseudunio auricularius has been mainly due to the disappearance of the migratory host fish. Damming and impounding of rivers is probably also the cause for the rarefaction of this species also.
evaluator: van Damme. D., Ghamizi, M., Soliman, G. & McIvor, A.

rationale: This is a widespread species that is locally abundant with no major threats and therefore it is listed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Elfes, C., Carpenter, K.E. & Knapp, L.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large range extent, large population, apparently stable trend, and lack of major threats.

Sphoeroides maculatus is distributed in the North-Western Atlantic, from Newfoundland to northeastern Florida, USA. It has been found at depths of up to 274 metres, however it is concentrated in much shallower waters of about 20 meters. The centre of distribution for Sphoeroides maculatus is between the states of New Jersey and North Carolina. It is most commonly found at depths of less than 20 metres, however it has been recorded at depths of up to 200 m. This species undergoes migrations into the Chesapeake Bay to Spawn. At various times S. maculatus has been commercially and recreationally targeted throughout its range. Although it no longer supports a commercial fishery, in the wake of World War II it was heavily marketed as a low-cost alternative to meat during widespread food rationing and became widely appreciated as a delicacy. The fishery expanded, with peak landings declared in the 1960s. Decreases in landings from the 1970s onward are accompanied by widespread concern that S. maculatus populations were being severely reduced by a combination of commercial fishing and environmental degradation of nearshore waters. Whether or not this is actually the case is unclear. Data from a number of fisheries-independent surveys suggest that this species may naturally undergo dramatic fluctuations in abundance throughout its range, and there are several reports of localized increases in abundance which spawned small fisheries. Sphoeroides maculatus is still considered a delicacy, particularly in the Chesapeake Bay, and is landed by recreational fishers. It has never been managed. Sphoeroides maculatus is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Shao, K., Liu, M., Hardy, G., Jing, L., Leis, J.L. & Matsuura, K.

rationale: Lagocephalus lagocephalus is found in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans, in tropical and subtropical waters. It has been reported to depths of 1,000 m. It appears to be abundant in some parts of its range. This species is primarily oceanic, but may occasionally enter estuaries. There are no confirmed species-specific threats to L. lagocephalus. Its distribution overlaps with marine protected areas. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Hardy, G., Jing, L., Leis, J.L., Liu, M., Matsuura, K. & Shao, K.

rationale: Lagocephalus lagocephalus is found in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans, in tropical and subtropical waters. It has been reported to depths of 1,000 m. It appears to be abundant in some parts of its range. This species is primarily oceanic, but may occasionally enter estuaries. There are no confirmed species-specific threats to L. lagocephalus. Its distribution overlaps with marine protected areas. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Hardy, G., Jing, L., Leis, J.L., Liu, M., Matsuura, K. & Shao, K.

rationale: This species is listed as Vulnerable in the 2014 Chinese Red List. However, there is no information to make a full threat evaluation. It has a wide but fragmented distribution across China and so may qualify as Least Concern. However, there is some confusion regarding the range due to widespread cultivation, which needs further research. Due to this uncertainty, the species is listed as Data Deficient. More research is needed on the population size, trends, distribution and threats to this species.

This species is classified as Vulnerable as the extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,949 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs at four locations and, although it remains common in protected areas, its range is relatively restricted and populations are declining outside protected areas as a result of deforestation. The species may be reassessed as more threatened with further research.

Magnolia championii is classified as Data Deficient as there are no published data or information about population trends or the total number of individuals for this species. There is very little information about its extent of occurrence or its area of occupancy. There is insufficient information to assess this species against any criteria. It is listed as Endangered in the China Species Red List.

Magnolia championii is classified as Data Deficient as there are no published data or information about population trends or the total number of individuals for this species. There is very little information about its extent of occurrence or its area of occupancy. There is insufficient information to assess this species against any criteria. It is listed as Endangered in the China Species Red List.

Magnolia balansae is classified as Data Deficient as there is no published data or information about population trends or total number of individuals for this species. It may be classified as Least Concern due to its wide distribution in China, but there is habitat loss in parts of its range. Its distribution in Viet Nam is unclear, however the number of trees is known to be declining as it is a timber species.
