However, its rate of decline is not believed to be sufficient to trigger listing in a more threatened category, and so it is retained in Least Concern.
evaluator: Black, P.A. & Gonzalez, S. (Deer Red List Authority)

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because of its wide distribution, large population, occurrence in a number of protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
assessor: Csorba, G., Bumrungsri, S., Francis, C., Bates, P., Ong, P., Gumal, M., Kingston, T., Heaney, L., Balete, D., Molur, S. & Srinivasulu, C.
evaluator: Hutson, A.M., Racey, P.A. & Cox, N.A.

taxonomicnotes: This may be a complex of two distinct species, with Chaerephon nigeriae in the north of the known distribution and C. spillmani in the south. We follow Simmons (2005) in currently recognizing spillmani Monard, 1933 as a subspecies of nigeriae.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Mickleburgh, S., Hutson, A.M., Bergmans, W. & Cotterill, F.P.D.
evaluator: Hutson, A.M., Racey, P.A. & Cox, N.A.

taxonomicnotes: Mendelson et al. (2005) recently separated I. pisinnus (endemic to Mexico), I. porteri (endemic to Honduras), and I. signifer (endemic to Panama) from I. coccifer.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Santos-Barrera, G., Savage, J., Bolaños, F. & Chaves, G.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Solís, F., Ibáñez, R., Santos-Barrera, G., Jungfer, K., Renjifo, J. & Bolaños, F.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

taxonomicnotes: The taxon was reviewed and separated into several species by Haddad and Martins (1994). At present this species includes the Venezuelan population of Heatwole, Heatwole and Solano (1965). It is thought to be a composite species (see Frost, 2007).
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: La Marca, E., Azevedo-Ramos, C., Silvano, D., Hoogmoed, M., De la Riva, I., Reichle, S. & Acosta-Galvis, A.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

taxonomicnotes: This form is a complex of several species. G. piperata was recently separated out by Duellman and Köhler (2005). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Angulo, A., De la Riva, I., Jungfer, K., Córdova-Santa Gadea, J. & Sinsch, U.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

taxonomicnotes: This species was known as Leptodactylus fragilis for many years until Heyer (1978) determined that L. labialis and L. fragilis represent the same species and that the former was the correct name based on publication priority. However, Heyer (2002) later determined that Leptodactylus fragilis is in fact the valid scientific name for the species.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Ronald Heyer, Andrés Acosta-Galvis, Abraham Mijares, Frank Solís, Roberto Ibáñez, Geoffrey Hammerson, Jay Savage, Larry David Wilson, Federico Bolaños, Gerardo Chaves, Javier Sunyer
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson, Neil Cox and Bruce Young)

taxonomicnotes: There are many confusing variants, and erroneous attributions of Xenophrys aceras to Megophrys monticola. Research is needed to confirm whether or not the animals from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra belong to the same species.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.

taxonomicnotes: This species was placed in the genus Amolops by Dubois (1986).
rationale: Listed as Near Threatened since the species depends on streams in primary forest, and so its Area of Occupancy is probably not much greater than 2,000km2, and the extent and quality of its habitat is declining, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
assessor: Peter Paul van Dijk, Nguyen Quang Truong, Annemarie Ohler, Lu Shunqing, Yang Datong
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson and Neil Cox)

taxonomicnotes: This species was inadvertently named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists of Threatened Species. This species is named from the Nicobar Islands, and it is very likely that the animals on these islands will prove to be different from the populations in Southeast Asia (I. Das pers. comm.). In addition, the animals designated as Hylarana nicobariensis in the Thai-Malay Peninsula are a very different taxon from the 'nicobariensis' in Java and Bali, Indonesia.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Diesmos, A., Iskandar, D., van Dijk, P.P., Inger, R., Das, I. & Vijayakumar, S.P.
evaluator: Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Stuart, S.N.

taxonomicnotes: This species is considered to be incertae sedis within the genera Hoplobatrachus or Fejervarya by Dubois (1986).
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing doubts as to its taxonomic validity, extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson and Neil Cox)

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Dutta, S., Sengupta, S., Uddin Sarker, S. & Sharif Khan, M.
evaluator: Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Stuart, S.N.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although its Extent of Occurrence is much less than 5,000 km2, it is common, adaptable, and does not appear to be in decline.
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson and Neil Cox)

taxonomicnotes: We follow Dubois (1986) in considering Polypedates himalayensis to be a subspecies of this species.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Sushil Dutta, Kelum Manamendra-Arachchi, Karthikeyan Vasudevan, Chelmala Srinivasulu, S.P. Vijayakumar, Debjani Roy, Saibal Sengupta, Annemarie Ohler, Ghazi S.M. Asmat
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson and Neil Cox)

authority: Mateo, García Márquez, López Jurado & Barahona, 2001
taxonomicnotes: This taxon was originally described as a subspecies of Gallotia simonyi by Mateo et al. (2001), but we follow Afonso and Mateo (2003) in treating it as a full species. There is an urgent need to establish the identity of recently observed animals in northern La Palma (Mínguez et al. 2007) which might represent a remnant population of this species.
rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because any remnant population possibly totals fewer than 50 mature individuals. It is also possible that this species will qualify for the C2a(i) criteria, however additional studies are needed into the total population number and current population trend.
assessor: Jose Antonio Mateo Miras, Iñigo Martínez-Solano
evaluator: Cox, N. and Temple, H.J. (Global Reptile Assessment)

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the absence of recent information on its extent of occurrence, ecological requirements, threats and conservation status.
evaluator: Cox, N., Chanson, J.S. & Stuart, S.N. (Global Reptile Assessment Coordinating Team)

taxonomicnotes: Johnson et al. (2008) did not find evidence to support E. cinereiceps as a separate taxon from E. albocollaris , and that priority should be given to the senior synonym, E. cinereiceps, as the valid name.
rationale: There is a suspected population reduction of ≥80% in this species over a three generation period (24 years, estimating the generation length to be 8 years). This time period includes both the past and the future. Causes of this reduction (which have not ceased) include continuing decline in area, extent and quality of habitat, and exploitation through unsustainable levels of hunting. In 1997 a powerful cyclone reduced coastal populations by about 50%. Furthermore, E. cinereiceps has undergone significant hybridization with E. rufifrons in the northern part of its range (about half of its total distribution), whilst coastal populations have simultaneously suffered a significant genetic bottleneck. Based on these premises, the species is listed as Critically Endangered.
assessor: Andriaholinirina, N., Baden, A., Blanco, M., Chikhi, L., Cooke, A., Davies, N., Dolch, R., Donati, G., Ganzhorn, J., Golden, C., Groeneveld, L.F., Hapke, A., Irwin, M., Johnson, S., Kappeler, P., King, T., Lewis, R., Louis, E.E., Markolf, M., Mass, V., Mittermeier, R.A., Nichols, R., Patel, E., Rabarivola, C.J., Raharivololona, B., Rajaobelina, S., Rakotoarisoa, G., Rakotomanga, B., Rakotonanahary, J., Rakotondrainibe, H., Rakotondratsimba, G., Rakotondratsimba, M., Rakotonirina, L., Ralainasolo, F.B., Ralison, J., Ramahaleo, T., Ranaivoarisoa, J.F., Randrianahaleo, S.I., Randrianambinina, B., Randrianarimanana, L., Randrianasolo, H., Randriatahina, G., Rasamimananana, H., Rasolofoharivelo, T., Rasoloharijaona, S., Ratelolahy, F., Ratsimbazafy, J., Ratsimbazafy, N., Razafindraibe, H., Razafindramanana, J., Rowe, N., Salmona, J., Seiler, M., Volampeno, S., Wright, P., Youssouf, J., Zaonarivelo, J. & Zaramody, A.

taxonomicnotes: This ill-defined taxon was described as a subspecies of Crocothemis erythraea by Morton (1920). Waterston and Pittaway (1991) considered it as a good species, but few constant structural criteria allow the separation of both taxa (Morton 1920, Asahina 1973, Schneider 1985). Criteria used are structural ones, colour differences, a smaller size and minor venational characters. A taxonomic revision of the C. erythraea-complex over its whole range is urgently needed.
rationale: Given the fact that this taxon is poorly understood and few recent records are available, no conservation status is attributed, and the taxon is assessed as Data Deficient.
assessor: Boudot, J.-P., Schneider, W. & Samraoui, B.

taxonomicnotes: According to FishBase Poeciliopsis occidentalis sonoriensis is valid as Poeciliopsis occidentalis, (Baird & Girard, 1853) . But following Eschmeyer seems to be valid as a subspecies

Although there is great variation in habit and stature in the trees associated with different habitats there are no clear boundaries between the different forms. The most useful taxonomic treatment is to give names to the most distinct, but only at the varietal level. Therefore var. pubescens for the tall central European and souther British and Scandinavian populations, var. pumila for northern populations, whcih are probably derived from var. pubescens through adaptive selection and introgression from B. nana, var. fragrans for aromatic, small leaved trees from northwest Britain, and var. litwinowii for Anatolian and Caucasian populations which are probably largely the result of introgression from B. pendula

Betula coriacea and B. concinna from Sweden remain enigmantic, similar to one another, and distinct from other forms of B. pubescens

Betula turtuosa, B. borysthenica, B. kusmischeffii, B. rezniczenkoana, B. kelleriana, B. ircutensis and B. baicalensis await further study
rationale: Although locally rare and considered threatened in some areas (listed as Critically Endangered in Croatia, Vulnerable in Hungary and Bosnia and Herzegovina, Near Threatened in Luxembourg) it is considered to be of Least Concern over much of its range (including in Denmark, Estonia, Norway, Switzerland and Great Britain). The population of this species is declining in some areas, including southern Europe, due to a decline in peat bog habitats. However, given its widespread distribution, common occurrence throughout Europe, the presence of stable populations and the absence of major threats across much of its range, this species has been classified as Least Concern overall.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: Magnolia champaca is classified as Least Concern as it is widespread in the Indo-Malaysian tropical region. There are no specific population information or data on decline of this species. It is used for timber but logging is not thought to be a significant threat to the species at a global level.

There are no published data about population trends or total numbers of  mature individuals for this species.  There is very little available  information about its extent of occurrence or its area of occupancy.   There have been no quantitative analyses examining the threats and probability of  extinction of this species.  As a result, the assessors have  insufficient data to assess the species against the IUCN  criteria.

There is currently insufficient information on population trends and threats for Magnolia biondii. However, it has a very widespread distribution with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of more than 250,000 km2 and therefore, it is classified as Least Concern. It is listed as Least Concern in the 2014 Chinese Red List.

There is currently insufficient information on population trends and threats for Magnolia biondii. However, it has a very widespread distribution with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of more than 250,000 km2 and therefore, it is classified as Least Concern. It is listed as Least Concern in the 2014 Chinese Red List.

There is currently insufficient information on population trends and threats for Magnolia biondii. However, it has a very widespread distribution with an extent of occurrence (EOO) of more than 250,000 km2 and therefore, it is classified as Least Concern. It is listed as Least Concern in the 2014 Chinese Red List.

Magnolia laevifolia is classified as Data Deficient as there is no published data or information on any population trends or its extent of occurrence. Further research is required to accurately determine if this species is threatened.

Magnolia laevifolia is classified as Data Deficient as there is no published data or information on any population trends or its extent of occurrence. Further research is required to accurately determine if this species is threatened.

taxonomicnotes: Previously considered to belong to a separate genus Parakmeria
The species is frequently divided into subspecies but the differences between the two forms are not thought to be sufficient for taxonomic distinction.

rationale: Magnolia fistulosa is classified as Data Deficient here. The scope of the threats to the species are unknown across the species range. A survey carried out by the Global Trees Campaign in 2005 estimated that there were less than 200 individuals remaining but this is likely to be an estimate of the subpopulation size in Yunnan (previously called Magnolia phanerophlebia). It may also sometimes been treated under Magnolica champacifolia and as Magnolia albosericea.
assessor: Rivers, M.C., Wheeler, L. & Khela, S.

taxonomicnotes: Considered a valid species (S. lavandulifolia Vahl.) by Castroviejo et al. 2010, G. Blanca pers. comm. 2014).
rationale:
Global, European, EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This subspecies is considered to be restricted to Spain, with records from France and Italy considered to refer to other taxa. Assessed as Least Concern as there are no known threats and it appears to be locally abundant.
evaluator: Sáez Goñalons, L., Leaman, D.J. & Allen, D.J.

taxonomicnotes: Considered a valid species (S. lavandulifolia Vahl.) by Castroviejo et al. 2010, G. Blanca pers. comm. 2014).

taxonomicnotes: Magnolia purpurascens (Maxim.) Makino is an illegitimate synonym.
rationale: Magnolia sprengeri is listed as Vulnerable in the China Species Red List. However, there is no published information on population declines or threats. It is assumed to be Least Concern based on its large, but fragmented, distribution.

Magnolia yunnanensis is classified as Data Deficient as there is no information on the population and more research is required to accurately determine its threat status. It has a relatively wide distribution in China. It was listed as Endangered in the China Plant Red Data Book.

taxonomicnotes: This species is in Flora of China as Michelia mediocris Dandy.
rationale: Magnolia mediocris has been assessed as Least Concern, based on its wide distribution. It is considered common in some areas, and known to be declining in other areas but not currently at a rate which warrants a threatened rating. Its timber is valued for construction and the seeds are collected for medicinal purposes which may effect the regeneration of this species, however more research is needed to determine population trends and harvest use for this species if it is to be assessed as threatened. Magnolia mediocris has been assessed as Least Concern in the 2014 Red List of China. It is potentially Vulnerable in Viet Nam where the potential forest distribution is 9,073 km2 which is also continuing to decline in area and quality.

taxonomicnotes: In Flora of China as Manglietia insignis (Wallich) Blume
rationale: Magnolia insignis is classified as Least Concern as it has a wide distribution and is very common in China. It is threatened in Thailand where it is rare and it remains unclear if this species is native to Thailand. It is listed as Vulnerable in the China Plant Red Data Book.

taxonomicnotes: Michelia parviflora Merr. is an illegitimate synonym.
rationale: Magnolia compressa is classified as Data Deficient as there is no published data or information about population trends or total number of individuals for this species. There is very little information about its extent of occurrence or its area of occupancy. There have been no quantitative analyses examining the threats and probability of extinction of this species. There is insufficient information to assess this species against the criteria.

Although there is no published data or information about population trends or total number of individuals for this species it can be classified as Least Concern as it has a large enough distribution in Viet Nam not to be deemed threatened. However, based on its scattered and fragmented distribution in China it may become threatened. More information is needed on the threats and evidence of declines.

There is insufficient information to assess this species against any criteria.

taxonomicnotes:
Cypripedium variegatum Georgi. is an invalid synonym

Cypripedium orientale Spreng. is an illegitimate synonym
rationale: Cypripedium guttatum is local with a very large distribution area and aggregations of various size and numbers. Population are declining in European Russia but stable in North America. From a global view and the wide distribution range (the extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of the species are well in excess of 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2 respectively) the species is at low risk of extinction as the existing threats to the species and its habitats are unlikely to cause the species to decline rapidly in the near future, in particular if the conservation measures suggested are applied.  The species is protected in 27 Zapovedniks and national parks in Russia, listed by the U.S. Federal Government in Alaska. C. guttatum is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

Magnolia acuminata is classified as Least Concern. Although published data on this species is not available it is known to have a widespread distribution in eastern North America where it is common. It remains unclear if this species is restricted to high elevations and montane areas. There are no known threats to this species and populations are thought to be stable.

Magnolia acuminata is classified as Least Concern. Although published data on this species is not available it is known to have a widespread distribution in eastern North America where it is common. It remains unclear if this species is restricted to high elevations and montane areas. There are no known threats to this species and populations are thought to be stable.

taxonomicnotes: Note that contrary to Hunt et al. (2006) F. santa-maria and F. townsendianus are treated as synonyms of F. peninsulae.
rationale: Ferocactus peninsulae is listed as Least Concern because it has a wide range (extent of occurrence over 50,000 km2), and even though there are localized threats throughout its range, these are not sufficient to trigger a threatened listing. Illegal collection is the main concern, if it continues at the same rate it could affect the population. Hence ongoing population monitoring is urgently needed.
assessor: León de la Luz, J.L., Hernández, H.M. & Gómez-Hinostrosa, C.
evaluator: Goettsch, B.K., Hilton-Taylor, C. & Superina, M.

taxonomicnotes: This taxon has been considered a junior synonym of Agama agama elongis since shortly after its description. Böhme et al. (2005), in distinguishing the East African A. lionotus complex from A. agama, gave turuensis as the name of a presumably valid subspecies of A. lionotus, separate from A. lionotus elongis. This arrangement was not discussed, and A. turuensis therefore remained a junior synonym of A. l. elongis until the examination of new material by Wagner et al. (2008) determined that A. turuensis represents a valid species separate from A. lionotus.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is known from a number of localities and is probably more widespread than is currently known, it is expected to be common, it is associated with rocky habitats that are not subject to major threats and can be found close to villages, suggesting a degree of adaptability.

taxonomicnotes: The relationship of this species with the very similar species P. armandii, P. fenzeliana and P. morrisonicola and the infraspecific taxa in this group of East Asian pines belonging to subsection Strobus is in need of further investigation using DNA sequence data. Pinus amamiana may be most distinct in its cones and seeds, which seem to be more morphologically adapted to seed dispersal by birds and rodents, with small cones and relatively large, virtually wingless seeds. However, from DNA analysis of other pines with such cones (e.g. P. albicaulis and P. cembra) strong selective pressure has determined the evolution of these adaptations and they are not necessarily good indicators of phylogenetic relationships.
rationale: This species meets the thresholds for Endangered under both criteria A and B. Even though exploitation has ceased, the more recent infestation with pine nematodes continues to cause serious population decline.

Pomatoschistus lozanoi is restricted to the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, from the North Sea to Portugal, although the distribution within this range is not continuous. Pomatoschistus lozanoi is abundant where it occurs and the population is assumed to be stable. There are no known, widespread threats. Therefore, P. lozanoi is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Herler, J., Kovacic, M. & Williams, J.T.
evaluator: Ahnelt, H., Larson, H. & Harvey, M.

taxonomicnotes: Trees from the extremes of the distribution in Europe (Betula pendula), northeast Asia and Japan and western North America (B. platyphylla, B. mandshurica, B. neoalaskana) and southwest China and Tibet (B. szechuanica) look different and can be distinguished from one another. However, when the whole continuous geographical range of diploid silver birches is considered, all those named as species intergrade in geographically intervening areas. It is thought to be best divided into three subspecies, ssp. pendula in Europe and eastwards to central Asia, ssp. mandshurica in eastern Asia and western North America and ssp. szechuanica in western China from Qinghai and Gansu to Yunnan and southeast Xizang. Betula platyphylla has been described as a seperate species, representing birches from Mongolia east of the Altai and into western and northeastern China but it is thought the two are synonymous. Betula oycoviensis previously listed as threatened is a form of B. pendula. Betula pendula ssp. font-queri and B. pendula ssp. parvibracteata, previously listed as threatened are thought to be only minor variants of B. pendula. Betula szaferi, described previously as Extinct in the Wild, is now considered a weak growing, precociously and heavily fruiting form of B. pendula, due to the presence of a mutant gene
rationale: Betula pendula is classified as Least Concern due to its widespread distribution, stable populations and no major threats.
assessor: Stritch, L., Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: Apletodon bacescui is known from the southwestern Black Sea to the central Black Sea coast of Turkey. The species is cryptic and is likely to be under-represented in surveys. There are minimal data for this species and it occupies only a small area. However the species is not considered likely to be impacted by known threats in the Black Sea and it occurs in protected areas. Therefore, Apletodon bascescui is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Williams, J.T., Herler, J. & Kovacic, M.

taxonomicnotes: This species has only recently been recognized (Mill and Whiting 2012). Prior to this, plants representing this taxon were recognized as Podocarpus spathoides de Laub. or as P. spathoides var. solomonensis Silba. Podocarpus spathoides is restricted to Peninsular Malaysia and possibly one or two other localities in western Malesia.
rationale: Podocarpus orarius has only recently been recognized and its distribution, population size and status are poorly known. In some localities, mining and logging are impacting its known habitat. At this stage, an assessment of Near Threatened is the most precautionary approach to take, it is probably close to meeting criterion B2ab(iii) for listing as threatened. A new assessment will be required when new information becomes available.

taxonomicnotes:
Although there is great variation in habit and stature in the trees associated with different habitats there are no clear boundaries between the different forms. The most useful taxonomic treatment is to give names to the most distinct, but only at the varietal level. Therefore var. pubescens for the tall central European and souther British and Scandinavian populations, var. pumila for northern populations, whcih are probably derived from var. pubescens through adaptive selection and introgression from B. nana, var. fragrans for aromatic, small leaved trees from northwest Britain, and var. litwinowii for Anatolian and Caucasian populations which are probably largely the result of introgression from B. pendula

Betula coriacea and B. concinna from Sweden remain enigmantic, similar to one another, and distinct from other forms of B. pubescens

Betula turtuosa, B. borysthenica, B. kusmischeffii, B. rezniczenkoana, B. kelleriana, B. ircutensis and B. baicalensis await further study
rationale: Although locally rare and considered threatened in some areas (listed as Critically Endangered in Croatia, Vulnerable in Hungary and Bosnia and Herzegovina, Near Threatened in Luxembourg) it is considered to be of Least Concern over much of its range (including in Denmark, Estonia, Norway, Switzerland and Great Britain). The population of this species is declining in some areas, including southern Europe, due to a decline in peat bog habitats. However, given its widespread distribution, common occurrence throughout Europe, the presence of stable populations and the absence of major threats across much of its range, this species has been classified as Least Concern overall.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species is considered to occupy less than 500 km² of river, but this estimate is probably nearer to 100 km² in three river systems. The species' range is declining. The subpopulations are severely fragmented and occur in very low numbers.

taxonomicnotes: Hemidactylus boavistensis has long been treated as a subspecies of H. bouvieri, but was re-elevated to species status by Arnold et al. (2008) based on morphological and molecular evidence.
rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species, although restricted to two islands and two islets in Cape Verde, is still abundant despite ongoing pressures from development and introduced species, and so is unlikely to be at imminent risk of extinction. The species almost meets the requirements for listing as threatened under criterion B1ab(iii,v). This situation warrants monitoring and measures are required to ensure the effective protection of this gecko in order that it does not qualify for listing in a more threatened category in the near future.

This species is classified as Least Concern as it has a wide range in the Himalayas where it occurs at elevations over 2,500 m asl. It forms the dominant tree in some areas. Although it has declined substantially due to direct logging, the rate of decline is not thought to be sufficient to qualify the species as threatened. Further information is needed on the number of trees harvested and the wild population status.

It is classified as Least Concern by the Global Tree Specialist Group as it has a wide natural range, it is not known to be utilised for its timber and there is no current concern for its conservation status. However further information on population trends would be beneficial.

Magnolia kisopa has a wide range but its recruitment rate has substantially decreased by around 50%. The timescale over which these declines occurred are unknown. Further data is required to determine the exact rate of population declines and the causes of these declines which are not considered to be anthropogenic.
This species is classified as Least Concern due to its widespread distribution and lack of major threats. It is given a global ranking of G5 by NatureServe.
assessor: Khela, S., Wheeler, L. & Rivers, M.C.

rationale: This species is classified as Endangered as it is restricted to Assam with a potential forest distribution of 1,765 km<sup>2</sup>, and is found in less than five locations. Habitat loss is continuing throughout the species' range.

This species is classified as Data Deficient as there is no information on existing populations and the threats and uses are unknown. Its extent of occurrence is unlikely to fall within the thresholds for the threatened categories.

This species is classified as Data Deficient as there is no information on existing populations and the threats and uses are unknown. Its extent of occurrence is unlikely to fall within the thresholds for the threatened categories.
This species is classified as Least Concern as it has a wide distribution and there is no evidence of decline or fragmentation of the population.

This species is classified as Data Deficient as there is very limited information on the status of this species. Populations outside protected areas where deforestation for palm oil occurs remain unknown and further research is required.

taxonomicnotes: No infraspecific varieties are recognized for Abies concolor.
rationale: Abies concolor is an extremely widespread species that occurs in numerous locations throughout much of the mountainous western North America and, more scattered, into Mexico. Whilst undoubtedly logged in past and present, this has little impact on the total population. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes:
In addition to its overall appearance, its riparian habitat relates Arisaema heterophyllum to the American A. dracontium.

Specimens close to A. heterophyllum have been found on Mt. Emei (China), near the Baguo Monastery. Gusman and Gusman (2006) consider this a geographical form of A. heterophyllum, whilst deciding whether it deserves a subspecies status.
rationale: Arisaema heterophyllum is a perennial herb found in central and southern China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan and the Republic of Korea.  It has a large estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of more 2.5 million km2, This estimate is based on specimen data, some of which is old and some sub-populations may have been lost due to habitat conversion. However, the EOO is still inferred to exceed the threshold for a threatened category. It is often found in riparian forest and more open areas along watercourses and forest clearance, damming, pollution and conversion to rice and fish farming are all threats that are likely to directly affect this species. Its preference for riparian habitats may mean that the area of occupancy (AOO) is in decline due to the habitat changes currently occurring along many of the rivers in the region (although it was not possible to estimate actual values for present and future AOO). The species is considered threatened in Japan, where the majority of rivers have been stripped of their forest habitat (Oshima et al. 1997), and only a few patches remain. However, it is inferred that the area of occupancy (AOO) and population at present exceed the thresholds for a threatened category. In the Rare Plants Data Book of Korea it is listed as nationally Least Concern (Korea national Arboretum 2009). It is found within several protected areas and it is conserved ex situ in several botanical institutions around the world. It is assessed as Least Concern. Periodic monitoring is recommended to detect any declines as there are ongoing threats to habitat.

Pinus pumila has one of the most extensive ranges of all species, and has a habit (shrubby) and ecology that make it highly unlikely to go extinct in the foreseeable future. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

Pinus pumila has one of the most extensive ranges of all species, and has a habit (shrubby) and ecology that make it highly unlikely to go extinct in the foreseeable future. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

This variety, although less widespread than the nominate variety, still has an extent of occurrence and area of occupancy well beyond the threshold for a threatened category. Both its habit and its habitat make it unlikely that it is threatened in any way.

taxonomicnotes: Two varieties are recognized: the nominate variety (var. cuspidata) occurs throughout the range of the species and var. nana which is only known from Japan and the Russian Far East. The occurrence of this latter variety is poorly documented; both its taxonomic status and its occurrence are in need of further investigation.
rationale: Exploitation of this species has only affected subpopulations in certain parts of its extensive range, hence it is assumed that population reduction has been limited and has not had sufficient impact to warrant any assessment other than Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Two varieties are recognized: the nominate variety (var. cuspidata) occurs throughout the range of the species and var. nana which is only known from Japan and the Russian Far East. The occurrence of this latter variety is poorly documented; both its taxonomic status and its occurrence are in need of further investigation.
rationale: Exploitation of this species has only affected subpopulations in certain parts of its extensive range, hence it is assumed that population reduction has been limited and has not had sufficient impact to warrant any assessment other than Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Relatively recently published taxonomic revisions differ considerably in the way that they treat the status of this species. De Laubenfels (1985) considered it to be within P. aristulatus while Staszkiewicz (1988) recognized it as a subspecies of P. angustifolius. Stark Schilling (2004) recognized P. buchii as a distinct species. Clearly it is very closely related to the Cuban species within which some taxonomists have included it. For the purposes of this assessment it is treated as a distinct species under the name P. buchii.
rationale: Podocarpus buchii is distributed on the island of Hispaniola where it mainly occurs in the Dominican Republic and a small part of Haiti. In both countries it has suffered severe levels of habitat loss due to logging, forest clearance for agricultural and commercial plantations, fire and mining. The most severe habitat degradation and loss of locations is thought to have occurred in Haiti. The severity of loss is estimated as ca. 50% over three generations; a generation here is estimated to be between 25-30 years. In both countries there continues to be a decline in habitat quality even in the protected areas where this Podocarpus species occurs. As a result of this loss this species has been assessed as Endangered A2ac
