taxonomicnotes: Until recently, Tarentola rudis was considered a moderately widespread gecko in Cape Verde, where it was represented by five subspecies, including the nominate form (Vasconcelos et al. 2012). Molecular research indicates that this is a polyphyletic grouping, and consequently Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated T. r. boavistensis, T. r. protogigas and T. r. maioensis to species status, leaving a monotypic T. rudis.
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, although no major threats appear to exist, this species may occur at a sufficiently low population density and in such a small area to warrant listing in a threatened category and further research is required to clarify this. Research is also required to clarify the impact of hybridization with Tarentola darwini on the long-term viability of T. rudis.

taxonomicnotes: Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated this species, previously a subspecies of Tarentola caboverdiana, to species level based on molecular evidence.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species has a somewhat restricted range, it can be found in large numbers and does not appear to be subject to major threats.

taxonomicnotes: Vasconcelos et al. (2012) elevated this species, previously a subspecies of Tarentola caboverdiana, to species level based on molecular evidence.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species has a somewhat restricted range, it can be found in large numbers and does not appear to be subject to major threats.

taxonomicnotes: Chioninia nicolauensis was until recently treated as a subspecies of C. fogoensis. Molecular research conducted by Miralles et al. (2010) revealed that the two taxa are not closely-related, and these authors therefore elevated C. nicolauensis to species level.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species has an extent of occurrence of only 183 km<sup>2</sup>, it is very abundant within this range, adaptable, and not subject to major threats.

taxonomicnotes: This species is sometimes known as Trisetum canescens Buckley in the U.S.A.
rationale: This is a widespread species with no specific threats found in a variety of common habitats; Least Concern is the most appropriate category for this species.

taxonomicnotes: Brodiaea minor is very similar to B. purdyi, which may be only a subspecies of it (Flora of North America Editorial Committee 2002,Preston 2006).
rationale: Brodiaea minor is rated as Least Concern as it has a large extent of occurrence (EOO), and it is reported to be locally very common and abundant, readily reproduces by seeds, has a low habitat specificity and there are no major direct threats. Not many subpopulations appears to occur within protected areas, therefore the population should be monitored at regular intervals to detect any change in the population dynamics of this Californian endemic.

Carex rossii is very widely distributed, occurring in all the western parts of the USA and Canada and the large extent of occurrence (EOO) suggests it is not threatened. The taxon has been recently described as common and abundant in most of its range (specimen data, Ownbey and Morley 2005, Cole 2007, Jepson Flora Project 2008) and described as a dominant graminoid of the Pacific Northwest. Its occurrence being seemingly rarer east of the Rocky Mountains and in the upper Great Lakes region (Gerdes 2003). Carex rossii is locally rare and threatened in Ontario, Michigan, Nebraska, North Dakota, and Minnesota. Recent occurrences in New Mexico and Illinois have been reported where it is uncommon. Carex rossii occurs in 36 different ecoregions of Canada and the USA and is adapted to a wide range of habitats. Although there are general threats to plant species in these regions, these are not direct threats to C. rossii. The taxon is described as a strong competitor which thrives on hostile and disturbed sites and is a dominant understorey species in many communities where it occurs. Carex rossii is drought, trampling, browsing, and even oil spills tolerant and very hard to remove from places where it grows. The taxon is legally protected in Michigan, Nebraska and Ontario. where it is threatened and occurs in areas which benefit from some level of protection in all its range. Carex rossii was assessed as globally secure in the USA, by NatureServe, in 1988. There is no evidence to show that the status of the taxon has changed therefore C. rossii is assessed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Arnett, J., Bennett, B. & Heidel, B.

taxonomicnotes: The majority of the Borinda/Fargesia species were described for the first time in the 1980s, nearly all from sterile material, and often from a very limited number of collections. Considerable work remains to refine species delimitation, and to relate newly described species to earlier names based upon inadequate flowering specimens, many lacking vegetative parts (Stappleton 1998).
rationale: Fargesia albocerea may occupy an extremely restricted range being only known from the type locality. The exact extent of the range is difficult to estimate as level of survey effort in the region is not known. An estimate suggests it may be restricted to a forested area of between 1,000 and 5,000 km2 (Bystriakova et al. 2003) and it is reported as being endemic to the Gaoligong Mountains. Therefore, under criterion B the range in terms of extent of occurrence (EOO) may meet the Endangered category at the very least. Despite its occurrence within a protected area the species may still be subject to a variety of threats in the region, although it is not certain if a continuing decline can be inferred. Field surveys should be conducted in the region to determine the current range and size of the population of this narrow endemic bamboo. If the population is small and/or confirmed to occur at only one locality it may meet the threshold for a threat rating under criterion D and if a continuing decline is observed or inferred then criterion B or C may be applied. However, until more field work in the region is undertaken to gather more data a rating of Data Deficient is advised.
assessor: Bachman, S., Chadburn, H. & Romand-Monnier, F.

rationale: The estimated extent of occurrence for this grass falls below the threshold for a threatened category. However, all the collection records are from within long established protected areas and it is inferred that threats are minimized and managed and that there should not be any continuing declines. As the area inferred to be unaffected by threat is more than half the range the IUCN locations subcriterion is not applicable. It is not thought to be subject to extreme fluctuations or to be severely fragmented. The population is inferred not to be small, as it occurs over a range of altitudes and habitats and dominates some tussock grasslands. Although it is thought to meet the Vulnerable criteria under B1 it is not thought to satisfy the B subcriteria and it is assessed as Least Concern. Periodic monitoring is recommended to detect and document any declines.

Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

Artemisia umbelliformis is a naturally rare Alpine plant which has undergone declines as a result of indiscriminate picking for its use in the production of the liquor 'Genepi' (Bicchi et al. 1984, Binet et al. 2011). Its collection is now prohibited in Switzerland and Italy, but continues in France on a regulated level. It is widely cultivated within these regions for liquor production (except in southern France where it is still collected), which has relieved collection pressure on wild populations and thereby is preventing further declines. Its status in other countries within its range is more uncertain; there is a lack of information on the population and distribution in the Carpathian and Balkan mountains. Given its broad distribution and the protection measures currently in place across parts of its range (precisely in the regions where collection has been most well-documented), A. umbelliformis is provisionally listed as Least Concern. However, if its population is small and collection pressure is high across its range, and given its increased rarity, it may warrant listing in a higher category of threat.
evaluator: Leaman, D.J., Miller, R.M. & Oldfield, S.

rationale: Cypripedium fasciculatum is scattered widely across eight states in western North America. Most of the subpopulations are small and large subpopulations occur only occasionally.  The area of occupancy of C. fasciculatum is about 400 km2 and the species is under numerous threats, especially habitat destruction, tree harvesting, light regime disturbance, alteration of the moisture or temperature regime, browsing, grazing, trampling, road and trail construction, fire suppression and collection which cause a continuing decline of the species on all of the 7-10 estimated locations leading to the destruction of some subpopulations. The species is therefore assessed as Vulnerable (VU).

taxonomicnotes: Phylogeographic studies are recommended to clarify whether the isolated western record from the Ruwenzori Mountains is conspecific with Cnemaspis elgonensis (P. Wagner pers. comm. 2014).
rationale: Cnemaspis elgonensis is listed as Vulnerable on the basis that its area of occupancy, estimated from the approximate area of remaining forest within its range, is less than 2,000 km2, and as it is found in five discrete, heavily fragmented forest blocks it is considered to occur as a severely fragmented population. There is an ongoing decline in the extent and quality of forest habitat within this lizard's range as a result of human pressures including cattle grazing.
assessor: Wagner, P., Safari, I. & Chenga, J.

taxonomicnotes: This species has several synonyms, some have recently been separated from Caladenia dimorpha and Jones (2007) provides an account of the separation of these species when describing Stegostyla ustulata. However, the scientific evidence is still debated. Examination of the material from across the range and DNA analysis suggests that the delimitation of the species may be inconsistent and observed differences may have an ecological rather than a genetic basis in some cases (M.Clements pers. comm. 2014).
rationale: Herbarium records for this orchid have been found for Australian Capital Territory, Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania giving a large extent of occurrence, which exceeds the threshold for a threatened category. It is found in open forest habitats and is reported to be localized and sometimes locally common (Jones 2006, Royal Botanic Gardens and Domain Trust  2009). It is recorded from protected areas within its range and is common to abundant in many reserves although it is rarer towards the edges of its range (M. Clements pers. comm. 2014). It is inferred that the population and area of occupancy (AOO) also exceed the thresholds for a threatened category. It is assessed as Least Concern. However, due to the level of threats to native vegetation in some parts of its range, it is recommended that the population is monitored periodically to detect any declines.

Cypripedium passerinum is common to occasional in suitable habitat and rare in other parts of its range. The trend of the population is decreasing slowly and the total mature individuals varies between 1,200 to 10,000 individuals with extreme fluctuations. The area of occupancy of C. passerinumis is about 650 km2 and the population of the species and the habitats are under numerous threats especially overgrazing, livestock grazing, recreational activities, clear-cutting, deforestation, fires, timber harvesting and collection from the wild for horticultural or medicinal purposes which cause a continuing decline of the species and the destruction of some subpopulations. C. passerinum is therefore assessed as Vulnerable (VU).

taxonomicnotes: This is a member of the former Agama agama species complex, and is still treated within accounts for A. agama in some recent field guides (Spawls et al. 2002, Largen and Spawls 2010 - part). Böhme et al. (2005) distinguished the A. lionotus group, encompassing East African members of the former A. agama complex, from the A. agama group. A. l. dodomae has subsequently been elevated to full species status, including the subspecies A. d. ufipae (P. Wagner unpubl. thesis, Wagner et al. in review).
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is widespread in a variety of natural and modified habitats, and no major threats have been identified.

taxonomicnotes: This taxon was described as a subspecies of Lygodactylus angularis. The justification for considering it a full species is unclear, however, this appears to be the general usage in recent literature on East African Lygodactylus (Spawls et al. 2002, Röll et al. 2010) and is consequently followed here.
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that, while the only known locality lies within a protected area, this species' true distribution and its ecological requirements are unknown, and it is therefore not possible to determine whether it or its habitat are subject to any threats.
assessor: Msuya, C.A., Ngalason, W. & Howell, K.

taxonomicnotes: This species has historically been treated as a subspecies of Lygodactylus schlefferi, and this arrangement is still followed by Uetz and Hallerman (2012). Recent literature on East African reptiles (Spawls et al. 2002) and Lygodactylus (Röll et al. 2010), however, treats it as a full species, although the basis for this is unclear. Röll et al. (2010) included this species in genetic analysis and found it to be monophyletic within the L. schlefferi species group, but as these authors did not include L. schlefferi itself in their analysis the appropriate taxonomic status of L. laterimaculatus remains uncertain.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species, while known from only four localities, is known from large protected areas in a region with little habitat disturbance and is able to persist in urban centres as long as trees remain.
assessor: Spawls, S., Beraduccii, J. & Malonza, P.

taxonomicnotes: Spawls et al. (2002) assert that this species has been elevated from the synonymy of Lygodactylus schlefferi, however the basis for this is not clear. This scheme has, however, been followed subsequently (Röll et al. 2010) and is accepted here pending reevaluation of the taxonomic status of this species.
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that there is no definite information on the distribution or ecological requirements of or the threats to this poorly-known species and even its taxonomic validity requires confirmation.
assessor: Howell, K., Beraduccii, J. & Ngalason, W.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, despite its restricted range, this species is common, found in a protected area, and is not thought to be subject to major threats.
assessor: Msuya, C.A., Spawls, S. & Malonza, P.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, despite its restricted range, this species is common, found in a protected area, and is not thought to be subject to major threats.
assessor: Msuya, C.A., Spawls, S. & Malonza, P.

rationale: Areca macrocalyx is widespread across Maluku, New Guinea, the Bismarck Archipelago and the Solomon Islands. It occurs within protected areas, in numerous different ecosystems and is under no specific threat at present. Utilization is at subsistence level only. A rating of Least Concern is given.

taxonomicnotes: Lamb et al. (2010) elevated A. p. occidentalis to specific status based on morphological evidence and a highly allopatric distribution, an arrangement that had previously been suggested by Spawls et al. (2002). Lamb et al. (2010) also found A. p. tasmani to be nested within A. orientalis (itself a subspecies of A. meleagris prior to this revision) and formally synonymized it within this taxon. Following these changes, A. percivali is monotypic, representing only the former subspecies A. p. percivali. Unfortunately technical difficulties prevented the inclusion of A. p. percivali in the molecular analysis by Lamb et al. (2010) to elucidate its relationship with A. occidentalis and A. orientalis.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is regularly encountered, occurs in several protected areas, and is thought to be subject to at most localized pressures on its habitat.
assessor: Spawls, S., Malonza, P., Beraduccii, J. & Msuya, C.A.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that this species occurs over a restricted area, encompassing around 3,000 km<sup>2</sup> at suitable elevations in four isolated subpopulations, each of which can be considered a single location at risk from threats from human encroachment. At present, this species is well-protected and its population appears to be stable in at least one locality, however, should this situation change in future it will immediately warrant listing in a threatened category (almost qualifies for listing as threatened under criterion B1ab(iii)).

taxonomicnotes: Broadley (1996) revised southern African Lycophidion and elevated L. pembanum, previously considered a subspecies of L. capense, to specific status. This revision was based on museum material, as no recent records of this taxon exist. The collection of new specimens and their inclusion of genetic analysis may therefore be required to verify this assignment (P. Malonza pers. comm. 2014).
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species, whose taxonomy remains uncertain, has not been recorded since the 1940s and although historical records and comparisons with congeners suggest that it may be somewhat tolerant of habitat disturbance, nothing is known with certainty about its sensitivity to land use change or its population status.
assessor: Msuya, C.A., Spawls, S. & Malonza, P.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, although this species has a restricted range, it appears to be widespread in the dominant anthropogenic habitats on Pemba and is not thought to be subject to any threats.

taxonomicnotes: The specific epithet name refers to Kai (present-day Yamanashi Prefecture) where this species was found.
rationale: This species is endemic to Japan, occurring only in the deciduous broad-leaved forests on Honshu island (Yamanashi, Shizuoka and Tokyo prefectures). It has a very restricted distribution range, and at present only six herbarium specimens (Naruhashi 2806, 2087; Serizawa s.n., Kanai s.n., Serizawa and Naruhashi 8, 9) with precise locality data were found. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is between 400 and 1,000 km2.. It has been assessed as Vulnerable in the 1997 IUCN Red List of Threatened Plants (Walter and Gillett 1998) and as Critically Endangered in the Threatened Wildlife of Japan-Red Data Book (Environmental Agency of Japan 2000). It is suspected that the area of occupancy (AOO) is now very small and the number of locations to be three or four, with no known formal protection and ongoing threats. The population is noted to be fragmented and population densities are very low (L. Hill pers comm. 2013). The population may also be small and declining, although no numerical population data, relating to the wild populations, was found. It is thought that the threats to habitat within the area will result in a continuing decline in the area, extent and quality. Further surveys are needed to establish the current population size and monitoring is needed to detect and document any declines. This information may inform the use of other criteria for the assessment of this species. In this assessment it is evaluated as Endangered under criterion B.
The species is widespread with stable populations and no known major threats.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species is estimated to be much greater than the value needed for a threatened category, particularly as the outlying population in Morocco greatly extends the range. However, the area of occupancy (AOO) is inferred to be less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>, as this species is only locally frequent and has specific wet habitat requirements, which are limited within its range. The size of the population is unknown and with increasing urbanization and agricultural development the population may be subject to decline, surveys and monitoring are needed to confirm this. The species has a disjunct range, it is recorded from Morocco in the west and and Lebanon, Jordan, Israel and the Syrian Arab Republic in the east, with no records found for the countries between these areas. The records from Cyprus are now thought to be attributable to another species (Boyce 2006). The species in Morocco has been assessed as very rare (less than five locations) and loss of the populations here would result in a very large reduction in the EOO. In Jordan it is considered an endangered species (Al-Quran 2010). In Lebanon and Syria there are only a few known localities (Mouterde 1966, Tohme and Tohme 2007). In Israel it has been recorded frequently from Mt Hermon and Kyriat Ata and less frequently elsewhere. It is assessed as Near Threatened as the AOO is suspected to fall within the thresholds for a threatened category and there is a continuing decline in the area, extent and quality of habitat, but it is not thought to be subject to extreme fluctuations and the number of locations is greater than 10 (it almost qualifies for listing as threatened under criterion B2ab(iii)).

Cypripedium parviflorum is confined to North America with a large distribution area and abundant populations. There are currently between 81 and about 300 occurrences and a population trend decrease is suspected due to numerous threats. The extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of the species are greater than thresholds for any threatened categories and although there are threats to the species and its habitats these are unlikely to cause the population to decline quickly in the near future if we apply the conservation measures suggested, raise public awareness and keep the existing conservations measures in place. C. parviflorum is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

Betula nigra is a commonly encountered tree species, near permanent water. The species has a wide distribution across the United States of America. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. Climate change is expected to extirpate the species at its westernmost distribution, but this will be offset with its northern range limits expanding into New England, Ontario, Quebec and maritime provinces in Canada. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Betula kenaica is said to differ from B. papyrifera primarily in its smaller stature and in its smaller, blunter-tipped, more coarsely and regularly serrate leaves. It is best considered a westward extension of B. papyrifera into southern Alaska, perhaps affected by introgression from B. pendula ssp. mandshurica.
rationale:
Betula papyrifera is a widespread, commonly encountered tree of mixed hardwood/conifer forest ecosystems throughout Canada and the northern United States extending southward in the Appalachian Mountains where it is a component of high elevational spruce/fir forests. It is a common species occurring in nearly 40 northern forest types. In east and east-central Canada and United States it is a major component of two forest cover types: Paper Birch and Paper Birch-Red Spruce-Balsam Fir. In Alaska and western Canada paper birch is a major component three forest cover types: Black Spruce-Paper Birch, White Spruce-Paper Birch and Paper Birch.

There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect paper birch in the foreseeable future. Climate change will extirpate paper birch at its southernmost distribution. Especially in the mid to southern Appalachian Mountains but this may be offset with its northern range limits expanding in Quebec and Ontario, Canada. It is assessed as Least Concern.

Global and European regional assessment: Data Deficient (DD)
EU 27 regional assessment: Data Deficient (DD)

There is very little information available for Glechoma hirsuta. It is widespread in some countries (Croatia, Serbia) but declining substantially in others (Czech Republic); however, data are lacking across most of its range. It is therefore classed as Data Deficient. More research on the population size and trends, ecological requirements as well as potential threats is needed for this species.

This species has a limited natural range, but most of the range of this species occurs in protected areas. It also spreads readily and rapidly, and has become naturalised in much of Europe. It is therefore not considered to be threatened, however some threats have been identified, including; a reduction in clear cutting practices in protected areas which could have a negative impact on population growth, competition from other species, climate change at lower altitudes, and root rot caused by the pathogen Phytophthora alni. Active conservation management within protected areas and population studies are advised for this species, to ensure it does not become threatened in future. It is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Wilson, B. & Roy , S.

assessor: Shaw, K., Wilson, B. & Roy , S.

rationale: This is a commonly encountered tree species across its range. It is the commonest alder, occurring at higher elevations than any other alder in its geographic distribution. It is extensively planted in plantations throughout Mesoamerica and South America. There are no known threats impacting this species now or major threats predicted in the foreseeable future. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Alnus glutinosa has been called A . vulgaris Hill in some older literature; that name was not validly published (Flora of North America)
rationale: This species has a wide distribution across Europe and into North Africa. Although population size has not been quantified, it is not believed to approach threshold values for a threatened category. Due to the scattered nature of subpopulations, potential future threats exist, but these are not considered significant at present. The species is therefore evaluated as Least Concern. The species was previously categorised as Least Concern by participants of the IUCN SSC Central Asian regional tree red listing workshop, held in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan (11-13 July 2006) and published as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List in 2007. This species is listed as Least Concern in the national Red Lists of Denmark, Estonia, Norway, Luxembourg, Switzerland and Great Britain. The category remains unchanged.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species has a NatureServe Global Status of Secure, however the State Conservation Status of this species is Imperiled in Virginia and Vulnerable in Wyoming. It is listed as Least Concern in the National Red Lists of Estonia, Norway and Switzerland. This species has a very wide distribution and, although it is thought to be sensitive to local extinctions, there are no major threats impacting this species across its full range. It is therefore not considered to be threatened and is evaluated as Least Concern. Monitoring is advised to respond to any increases in threats.
assessor: Shaw, K., Wilson, B. & Roy , S.

rationale: This species has a NatureServe Global Status of Secure, however the State Conservation Status of this species is Imperiled in Virginia and Vulnerable in Wyoming. It is listed as Least Concern in the National Red Lists of Estonia, Norway and Switzerland. It is therefore not considered to be threatened and is evaluated as Least Concern. Monitoring is advised to respond to any increases in threats.
assessor: Shaw, K., Wilson, B. & Roy , S.

rationale: Alnus orientalis var. pubescens was listed as Rare in the 'List of Rare, Threatened and Endemic Plants in Turkey' and endemic to Turkey and Rare in the European Red List. This variety is now included in the species Alnus orientalis, the range of which extends beyond Turkey. Insufficient information is available on the distribution or population status of A. orientalis across its range, although threats are reported to be impacting upon part of the range of this species. This species is therefore assessed as Data Deficient. Further expert input and field research is required to verify the current distribution, population and threat status of this species.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: Alnus orientalis var. pubescens was listed as Rare in the 'List of Rare, Threatened and Endemic Plants in Turkey' and endemic to Turkey and Rare in the European Red List. taxonomicnotes: The conspecificity of the disjunct populations needs to be assessed. There is little variation between the few known specimens (M. Wake pers. comm. 2007).
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of continuing uncertainties as to its extent of occurrence, status and ecological requirements.
assessor: Santos-Barrera, G., Flores-Villela, O., Canseco-Márquez, L., Wilkinson, M., Wake, M. & Ponce-Campos, P.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

taxonomicnotes: This species was formerly considered a synonym of Pristimantis fenestratus by Lynch (1980), but it was elevated to species status by Kohler (2000a).
rationale: Listed as Endangered because its Extent of Occurrence is less than 5,000 km2, all individuals are in fewer than five locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in Bolivia.
assessor: Claudia Cortez, Steffen Reichle, Ignacio De la Riva, Jörn Köhler
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson, Neil Cox and Bruce Young)

taxonomicnotes: This species was split from Eleutherodactylus weinlandi (Hedges et al. 2008).
rationale: Listed as Near Threatened given that, even though it is a common species with the ability to survive in a variety of disturbed environments (is not severely fragmented and known from more than ten locations), it has an estimated extent of occurrence of 3,005 km<sup>2</sup> and its natural habitat in the Dominican Republic is declining. It almost qualifies for a threatened listing under criterion B1ab(iii).

taxonomicnotes: This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).
rationale: Listed as Endangered given that its extent of occurrence is estimated to be ca. 814 km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing and accelerated decline of its natural forest habitat in Haiti.

taxonomicnotes: This species was split from Eleutherodactylus audanti (Hedges et al. 2008).
rationale: Listed as Endangered given that its extent of occurrence is estimated to be 901 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in the Sierra de Neiba, in Hispaniola.

taxonomicnotes: This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).
rationale: Listed as Endangered given that its extent of occurrence is estimated to be 1,773 km<sup>2</sup>,  its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and although it exhibits a degree of tolerance to habitat modification, it probably cannot withstand wholesale clear-cutting, which is occurring to its forest habitat in Hispaniola.

taxonomicnotes: <span lang="EN-US">The columnar, fastigiate form of this cypress, an iconic feature of the (urban) landscape in the Mediterranean, is not to be equated with the true species. Linnaeus’s type specimen is from Crete and belonged to a tree that grew in the wild and most probably did not have this form. The columnar form is best considered a cultigen. It is not here included in the species.
rationale: This species in its uncultivated form is very widespread but scattered; large and viable subpopulations exist as well as relict trees without successful reproduction in situ. It will certainly be of regional concern, e.g. in Israel and Lebanon, but globally it is still too abundant to be threatened with extinction. Exploitation has largely ceased, except local use for firewood in wood-deficient areas.

Listed as Least Concern on the basis that, while this species has a restricted range, it is currently common, has adapted well to habitat modification on islands with a long history of human occupation, and appears not to be subject to any immediate threats. Rising sea levels resulting from climate change likely represent a long-term future threat.
assessor: Hamilton, A., Allison, A. & Tallowin, O.

rationale: This species has been recorded from only two specimens: one collected in Bougainville, and one from Kira Kira on the islands of Makira in the Solomon Islands. It is  assessed as Data Deficient, as currently its habitat preference, ecological requirements, distribution, abundance and any potential threats, are unknown.
assessor: Allison, A., Tallowin, O. & Hamilton, A.

taxonomicnotes: Long regarded as a subspecies of the widespread varanid lizard Varanus indicus (Mertens 1941), it was elevated to full species status by Sprackland (1994).
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern. The possibility of this species occurring on additional islands in the Solomons needs investigating, in light of the single specimen collected on Bougainville in 1944. Research is needed to assess this species' habitat requirements and abundance, and any significant destruction of mangrove forests on either of the two Solomon Islands where it occurs will require the re-assessment of this species .
assessor: Allison, A., Hamilton, A. & Tallowin, O.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern on the basis that this species is common and is not considered to be subject to any threats.
assessor: Trape, J., Wagner, P. & Wilms, T.

taxonomicnotes: This species had previously been synonymized with Leptotyphlops macrorhynchus.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution. The only known potential threat is the loss of its moist habitats to desertification, most likely to result if the frequency of droughts increases under climate change; as such this represents a future rather than imminent threat to this species.
assessor: Böhme, W., Mateo, J.A., Joger, U., Slimani, T., El Mouden, E.H., Geniez, P., Nouira, M.S., Wagner, P. & Wilms, T.

taxonomicnotes: Platyplectrurus madurensis was described by Beddome in 1877 based on specimens collected from Palni Hills in Tamil Nadu (Smith 1943). Some authorities synonymized the taxon ruhanae Deraniyagla 1954 with Platyplectrurus madurensis (see McDiarmid et al. 1999). However, recent studies treat the former species as distinct and assign it to the genus Uropletis. As the two taxa differ on scale counts (see Smith 1943, Wickaramasinghe et al. 2009), they cannot treated as belonging to one species, thus retaining Platyplectrurus madurensis Beddome, 1877 as endemic to south India and ruhanae Deraniyagla 1954 as endemic to southern Sri Lanka.
rationale: Platyplectrurus madurensis has been assessed as Endangered as it has restricted distribution both in extent and attitudinal range with an extent of occurrence and area of occupancy less than 1,000 sq km and 100 sq km, respectively. It is known only from a few records and is affected by decline in quantity and quality of habitat as there has been extensive deforestation and habitat loss in the area (two locations) where the species had been recorded.
assessor: Srinivasulu, C., Srinivasulu, B. & Ganesan, S.R.
evaluator: Auliya, M., Bowles, P., Vijayakumar, S.P., Sreekar, R., Prabhu, M., Ramesh, M., Madala, M. & Molur, S.

rationale: Cypripedium reginae is widespread and abundant throughout much of eastern North America with numerous large subpopulations, mostly in large colonies of several thousand plants. There are currently between 81 to less than 300 total occurrences of C. reginae and most of the subpopulations contain 10 to 100 plants. Although the area of occupancy of the species is 1,285 km2, the current population trend is stable. From its wide distribution the risk of extinction for this species is low and the current threats to the species and its habitats are unlikely to cause the population to decline quickly in the near future if we apply the conservation measures suggested, raise public awareness and keep the existing conversations measures in place. Therefore, C. reginae is assessed as Least Concern.

Cypripedium reginae is widespread and abundant throughout much of eastern North America with numerous large subpopulations, mostly in large colonies of several thousand plants. There are currently between 81 to less than 300 total occurrences of C. reginae and most of the subpopulations contain 10 to 100 plants. Although the area of occupancy of the species is 1,285 km2, the current population trend is stable. From its wide distribution the risk of extinction for this species is low and the current threats to the species and its habitats are unlikely to cause the population to decline quickly in the near future if we apply the conservation measures suggested, raise public awareness and keep the existing conversations measures in place. Therefore, C. reginae is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: On the IUCN Redlist, Cupressus goveniana subsp. pigmaea is considered to be an ecotype of C. goveniana var. goveniana. It is found on sterile hardpan soils: when the harpan is broken, or trees from those areas are grown under normal conditions, they grow normally.
rationale: This variety meets the B criterion for Endangered due to its limited area of occupancy (AOO) even when calculated with an enlarged grid width of 4 km due to missing map points in the northernmost subpopulation (formerly recognized as subsp. pigmaea). A continuing decline is suspected due to fire exclusion and indirect threats associated with urban developments.

This taxon has a relatively limited area of occupancy (here based on 10 km wide grid squares) of ca. 1,200 km² but it is not in decline. Inaccessibility of many of the subpopulations has prevented substantial exploitation in the past, while these are now often within protected areas. Subpopulations become increasingly fragmented (disjunct) in a gradient from north to south. Threats are potential, but not actual. Much of the population of this taxon is within protected areas

Widdringtonia whytei has been heavily exploited for more than 100 years. Its current actual area of occupancy is estimated to be about 845 ha. Continued illegal logging, combined with an increased frequency of fires, a lack of regeneration, the impact of invasive species, exotic pests and over collection of firewood is likely to produce a decline of more than 80% by 2030. As a result it is assessed as Critically Endangered under the criteria for A4 and B2.

taxonomicnotes: Specimens of this species may have been recorded as A. yunnanensis in the past; a critical investigation of all herbarium specimens would be desirable.
rationale: Currently only known from one locality in Viet Nam (Ngoc Linh mountain): further surveys are required to determine if it also occurs in nearby areas. No specific threats have been identified but infrastructure developments (highways), forest fragmentation and degradation of habitats resulting from conversion of forests at lower altitudes to agricultural use may pose a threat in the future and if any of these happen the species would quickly become Critically Endangered in a short time. As a result an assessment of Vulnerable under the D2 criterion has been made.
assessor: Nguyen, T.H., Phan, K.L., Nguyen, Q.H. & Thomas, P.

taxonomicnotes: This variety (following Farjon 2010) now includes A. guatemalensis var. tacanensis which was assessed previously as a separate variety on the IUCN Red List.
rationale: Historically A. guatemalensis var. guatemalensis has been an important timber tree and as a result considerable loss of forest cover has occurred which is estimated to be ca. 50% over three generations (a generation here is estimated to 25–30 years). The loss of forest due to logging still continues today but at a slower rate. The recent trend of using the species for Christmas decorations in Guatemala and expanding urbanization has added to its decline. The area of occupancy of what remains has been estimated as being 270 km2 which is well within the threshold of 500 km2 for being classified as ‘Endangered’. This estimate is based on 258 km2 given by Andersen et al. (2006) for 92 of the 119 known forests plus an estimate of between 0.15 and 0.20 km2 for the remaining 26 forests. Deforestation has caused severe fragmentation and there continues to be a decline in the extent of occurrence and area of occupancy which has led to the loss of some locations and a mature individuals. This variety has therefore been assessed as being ‘Endangered’ under the A2 and B2 criteria.

Abies kawakamii has a limited extent of occurrence and area of occupancy that are within the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2 criteria. Subpopulations could be considered severely fragmented and there are between five and ten locations when fire is considered as the main potential threat. However, as there is currently no evidence of a continuing decline, an assessment of Near Threatened is appropriate.
assessor: Thomas, P., Liao, W. & Yang, Y.

rationale: There are 24 mature trees in the current population. This very small population size means that it still meets the criteria for listing as Critically Endanger under Criterion D.
In the absence of any evidence for significant decline, Abies nephrolepis is assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Zhang, D, Katsuki, T. & Rushforth, K.

taxonomicnotes: In Turkey this taxon is treated as a distinct species (Abies equitrojani Asch. & Sint. ex Bois.) that is endemic to a single location on Kas Daghi (Mt Ida) in Balikesir while the subpopulation at Ulu Dagh is treated as a separate species - Abies bornmuelleriana Mattf. On the IUCN Red List, this second taxon is treated as conspecific with Abies nordmanniana ssp. equitrojani.
rationale: The total area of occupancy (AOO) for Abies nordmanniana ssp. equi-trojani is estimated to be ca 164 km2. Although there are no specific figures for the Abies forests in Ulu-Dagh National Park (Mt. Olympus), the park covers an area of 128 km2 and this figure is used as an estimate. The AOO of Kaz-Daghi is 36 km2 (Kaya 2008). There are numerous documented threats to the Kaz-Daghi subpopulation including loss of mature individuals due to local logging, acid rain and degradation to the habitat due to recreational activities and fire (Özel and Simser 2009, Satil 2009). Consequently this taxon is assessed as Endangered.

taxonomicnotes: Four varieties are recognized: var. gracilis  (Kom.) Farjon, only known from a single disjunct population on the Kamchatka Peninsula; var. mayriana Miyabe and Kudo, from Hokkaido and the Sakhalin Islands; var nemorensis Mayr, also from Hokkaido and Sakhalin and the typical variety. Each taxon has a separate assessment.
rationale: As the assessment of the most widespread and abundant variety of this species is Least Concern, the species as a whole also falls into this category.
assessor: Zhang, D, Katsuki, T. & Rushforth, K.

rationale: Cedrus atlantica has an estimated extent of occurrence greater than 20,000 km2. Its total actual area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be between 1,300 and 1,500 km2 (Terrab et al. 2008, Linares et al. 2011) and there are seven main locations. Range wide declines of up to 75% in area of occupancy are estimated to have occurred between 1940 and 1982. Recent droughts have led to further declines in many parts of its range and it is likely that they will continue if the regional climate continues to become more arid. Outbreaks of pests and diseases have exacerbated the situation. Without proper control measures in place these negative effects are likely to continue.  The decline over the last 50 years is sufficient to warrant an assessment of Endangered under the criteria for A2 (three generations is 90 years).

taxonomicnotes: The names Cedrus libani  var. stenocoma (O.Schwarz) Frankis and Cedrus libani  subsp. stenocoma (O.Schwarz) P.H.Davis have sometimes been used to differentiate the Turkish subpopulation. The trees in Turkey tend to have a more upright habit which may in part be as a result of the common practice of repeatedly cutting branches for fire wood (pers. obs.). This species is closely related to Cedrus brevifolia which is sometimes included as a variety of Cedrus libani (Farjon, 2010)
rationale: The area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,016.5 km<sup>2</sup><sub><sup>  </sup></sub>does not take into account the two remnant locations in the Black Sea region of Turkey but it is assumed that these will not take the AOO over the 2,000 km<sup>2</sup> threshold for Vulnerable B2. In total there are no more than 10 locations - two in Lebanon, one in Syria and seven in Turkey. The population is fragmented, particularly the Syrian and Lebanese subpopulations. The area of occupancy, the quality of habitat is in decline and there is a loss of mature individuals due to a range of detrimental factors including: grazing by goats, urbanization, selective cutting, pest infestation and severe damage in some of the Lebanese forests due to winter sports.
This variety is too common in the forests of which it is a constituent to be of conservation concern.

Pinus halepensis has a very extensive extent of occurrence (EOO) and although considered threatened locally (Algarve in Portugal, Costa Brava in Spain) elsewhere it is stable or perhaps expanding as its economic use for timber has at least in its native habitat diminished. The species is listed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: In some literature, Pinus leucodermis is still treated as a species or infraspecific taxon under P. heldreichii, but it is becoming more generally accepted that the two are not distinct and should be treated as one single species without varieties or subspecies. The earliest name then applies.
rationale: Although scattered, Pinus heldreichii has a large extent of occurrence and is known from many healthy natural stands. Hybridization could be a threat but its occurrence needs to be confirmed, as well as the level of it if it occurs. Until then, it is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: In some literature, Pinus leucodermis is still treated as a species or infraspecific taxon under P. heldreichii, but it is becoming more generally accepted that the two are not distinct and should be treated as one single species without varieties or subspecies. The earliest name then applies.
rationale: Although scattered, Pinus heldreichii has a large extent of occurrence and is known from many healthy natural stands. Hybridization could be a threat but its occurrence needs to be confirmed, as well as the level of it if it occurs. Until then, it is assessed as Least Concern.
This widespread species, despite an area of occupancy that is probably under the threshold for Vulnerable, is not threatened as its population is thought to be stable.
evaluator: Perez de la Rosa, J. & Thomas, P.

taxonomicnotes: Two varieties are recognized (Farjon 2010): the typical variety and var apulcensis (Lindl.) Shaw. Both varieties are widespread and common and are assessed as Least Concern.
rationale: As this species is widespread and abundant throughout most of the southern half of Mexico and into Central America, it is assessed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Thomas, P. & Perez de la Rosa, J.

taxonomicnotes: Two varieties are recognized (Farjon 2010): the typical variety and var apulcensis (Lindl.) Shaw. Both varieties are widespread and common and are assessed as Least Concern.
rationale: As this species is widespread and abundant throughout most of the southern half of Mexico and into Central America, it is assessed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Thomas, P. & Perez de la Rosa, J.

taxonomicnotes: Two varieties are recognized (Farjon 2010): the typical variety and var apulcensis (Lindl.) Shaw. Both varieties are widespread and common and are assessed as Least Concern.
rationale: As this species is widespread and abundant throughout most of the southern half of Mexico and into Central America, it is assessed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Thomas, P. & Perez de la Rosa, J.

rationale: Past and recent exploitation has led to a decline of up to 40% within the last three generations. The area of occupancy has been reduced to less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. While there are more than 10 locations, the subpopulations are thought to be severely fragmented due to logging and conversion of forest lands to other uses. Exploitation is ongoing: if it continues at the same rate as in the recent past the overall decline is likely to exceed 40% within the next generation. Taken together, this indicates an assessment of at least Vulnerable under the criteria for A2, A4 and B2.
evaluator: Thomas, P. & Perez de la Rosa, J.

taxonomicnotes: Pinus funebris Komarov has been described as a separate species from North Korea and the adjacent Russian border area; some later authors considered it to be a variety of P. densiflora. Quite a number of other forms or varieties (e.g. P. densiflora var. ussuriensis T.N.Liou & Q.L.Wang - a synonym of P. sylvestris; P. densiflora var. zhangwuensis S.J. Zhang) were subsequently described and named, all from NE China. None of these are recognized here.
rationale: Due its very large extent of occurrence, Pinus densiflora is assessed as Least Concern despite continued exploitation in some parts of its range.

taxonomicnotes: More than 50 botanical varieties have been described for this species. Farjon (2010), only recognizes three of these. The typical variety is very widespread, from Scotland to Russian Far East. Pinus sylvestris var. hamata Steven is restricted to the Ukraine, Caucasus and Turkey. Pinus sylvestris var. mongolica Litv. is found in northern China, Mongolia and around Lake Baikal in Siberia. None of the varieties are considered to be threatened and are hence not assessed separately.
rationale: This is the most widespread of all pines, occupying many millions of hectares across Eurasia. Its tremendous distribution and large population size leads to an assessment of Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: More than 50 botanical varieties have been described for this species. Farjon (2010), only recognizes three of these. The typical variety is very widespread, from Scotland to Russian Far East. Pinus sylvestris var. hamata Steven is restricted to the Ukraine, Caucasus and Turkey. Pinus sylvestris var. mongolica Litv. is found in northern China, Mongolia and around Lake Baikal in Siberia. None of the varieties are considered to be threatened and are hence not assessed separately.
rationale: This is the most widespread of all pines, occupying many millions of hectares across Eurasia. Its tremendous distribution and large population size leads to an assessment of Least Concern.

This subspecies (or variety) of Pinus pinaster is very rare and known from only two widely separated populations on the African Mediterranean coast, the largest being in Morocco. These are relict occurrences and may indeed be genetically distinct. Logging and habitat degradation are known to occur but to what extent is presently unknown. Afforestation with other pines, especially with P. pinaster of European provenance, threatens the genetic integrity of these relict populations.

The successful eradication of goats recently on Guadalupe Island raises expectations that the subpopulation on that island may recover from a low of ca. 250 (over-)mature trees at present. The subpopulation(s) on Cedros Island are larger (a few thousand trees, but no census made) and regenerating well in the absence of goats.The restricted area of occupancy and two locations on two islands and the existence of a deadly pathogen affecting the mainland variety of this species puts the island variety at risk if that pathogen was introduced on one or both of the islands. It therefore meets criterion D2 for listing as Vulnerable.
evaluator: Perez de la Rosa, J. & Thomas, P.

taxonomicnotes: Subpopulations from the Daming Shan in Guangxi have been described as Pinus taiwanensis var. damingshanensis W.C.Cheng & L.K.Fu. On the IUCN Red List, P. taiwanensis is restricted to Taiwan. The Guangxi subpopulations are included with Pinus hwangshanensis.
rationale: This species is widespread but scattered and can be fragmented in certain areas where subpopulations are (now) separated by unsuitable habitat due to agricultural development. Yet its capacity to colonize does not seem to indicate any threat with extinction in the foreseeable future and it is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: This variety is sometimes treated as Pinus densata Mast. var. pygmaea J.R.Xue
rationale: This variety is relatively widespread and locally common. In the absence of any indication of significant past, recent or ongoing decline, it is best assessed as Least Concern.

Although for China assessed as Near Threatened by the IUCN SSC China Plant Specialist Group, this variety is too widespread there and elsewhere to be likely to move into a threatened category in the foreseeable future hence it is listed as Least Concern.

Although Dacrycarpus kinabaluensis has a very restricted distribution, there are no signs of decline or substantial damage to the population that could cause decline. Fire is a potential hazard, but is unlikely to affect substantial parts of the population which is widespread on the highest parts of the mountain. Most of the time the weather is wet with fog and rain and during dry periods a fire that was started would be localized.

taxonomicnotes: Formerly known as Podocarpus neriifolius D.Don var. atjehensis Wasscher, this taxon was elevated to species rank by David. J. de Laubenfels in 1985, who classified the two species in different sections based on vegetative characters. If it belonged with P. neriifolius, one of the most widespread species in the whole genus, the odd distribution would be explained.
rationale: The wide disjunction in the subpopulation should not be interpreted as a very large extent of occurrence (EOO) as there is no evidence that the species occurs between North Sumatera and West New Guinea. There is just one location known in New Guinea, but three in Sumatera, all in the north, and only these have been used to estimate the area of occupancy (AOO) and EOO. On this basis, both are small and fall well below the thresholds for listing as Endangered. Although past decline is suspected, there is no evidence of current decline and at least one subpopulation is within a protected area. Therefore, this species is best listed as Near Threatened until more information becomes available (almost qualifies for listing under criteria B1ab(v)+2ab(v)).

The very small extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of this species, which is confined to high altitude habitat on Mt. Kinabalu, places it close to a threatened category. However, the total known population is protected within Mt. Kinabalu N.P. and the only plausible threat, fires caused by tourism, has not (yet) materialized to the extent that it has adversely affected the population. These fires are likely to remain local due to climate and weather prevailing on the mountain. Near Threatened remains the best assessment of this species (it almost qualifies for a VU D2 listing).

taxonomicnotes: This species was originally described as a variety of the wide-spread species Podocarpus macrophyllus (Thunb.) Sweet by N.E. Gray, based on the collection R.C. Ching 2477 of which she had seen a specimen in the Herbarium of the Arnold Arboretum at Cambridge, Massachusetts. S.Y. Hu described it as a new species, based on the same type collection (R.C. Ching 2477) so in fact elevating Gray's variety in rank to a species. Two more collections were cited by Hu (Gray only knew the type), C.L. Tso 1477 from Jiangsu and W.P. Fang 14261 from Sichuan. A duplicate of C.L. Tso 1477 is in the Kew Herbarium (K); the collection from Sichuan could not be verified. This taxon was regarded as a cultivar of Podocarpus macrophyllus (cv. Chingii) by S.Y. Zhang in Flora of Zhejiang Province 1 (Lin and Zhang 1993), but there is no evidence of it having been found (only) in cultivation
rationale: In the absence of specific information about its distribution below the level of province, and in the absence of any information about population size or trends, Podocarpus chingianus is assessed as Data Deficient until further information becomes available.

Rapid change in land use involving the conversion of rainforest into rubber tree plantations have had an impact on the trees that occurred on the lower slopes of at least the southern subpopulations of this species, restricting them to the higher summit areas. This must have reduced the area of occupancy (estimated as 700 km2) as well as the habitat and numbers of mature trees; the population is now severely fragmented and the declines are continuing. On this Podocarpus ridelyi basis it is assessed as Vulnerable under the B2 criterion.

The area of occupancy is estimated to be 250 km2. Subpopulations are severely fragmented and a continuous decline is inferred from cutting and deforestation outside the protected areas. On this basis Podocarpus transiens is assessed as Endangered.

taxonomicnotes: The taxonomy of this variety is questionable. Rushforth (1987) has rejected alliance of this variety with A. vejarii and placed this taxon close to Abies durangensis. The latter species occurs in the Sierra Madre Occidental; A. vejarii is native in the Sierra Madre Oriental (including its varieties).
rationale: Known from four disjunct locations, and with an area of occupancy (AOO) of 36 km² or less, this variety is prone to stochastic events that could destroy a subpopulation. It qualifies for listing as Vulnerable under criterion D2, as if one or more subpopulation were destroyed it would move very quickly towards qualifying for listing as Critically Endangered.
evaluator: Thomas, P. & Perez de la Rosa, J.

rationale:
Global and European regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)
EU 27 regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)

Sideritis scardica is endemic to the Balkan Peninsula, where it is found at high altitudes in rocky montane areas. It is under intense collection pressure from the wild, with increasing demand for its medicinal value. The mass collection of generative shoots during the flowering phase combined with low germination of seeds has resulted in a significant population declines, at least in parts of its range, as the plant has been exploited for its herbal properties. It is not known to be extensively cultivated and although it occurs in protected areas and is a protected species in some countries, the degree of enforcement is unknown and collection is ongoing. Anthropogenic activities such as land use changes, trampling, ploughing, creation of forest trails, and grazing by cattle are additional threats.

Populations have been declining for several decades, particularly in Bulgaria (where the most population information is available), though the decline has not been quantified. Although conservation measures have been put in place in the past ten years, whether these have been effective is unknown; they have not been so in the past. The species is threatened in half of its countries of occurrence and its population appears to be quite small (<2,500 mature individuals in Bulgaria and >250 in Serbia), though population data are absent from the centre of its range in Albania, Macedonia and Greece, where populations might be larger (but demand is expected to remain high). Given the species' threatened status across much of its range, and considering the uncertainty in the population sizes and degree of decline, it is listed as Near Threatened approaching criteria A2cde.

Within the EU 27, it is present only in Bulgaria and Greece and is threatened in both countries. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 20,000-30,000 km². It is severely fragmented and suffering a continuing decline in both the quality of habitat and number of mature individuals. As the most intense collection pressure is in Bulgaria and Greece, and presuming population declines over the past 10-15 years have followed the same pattern as over the past few decades, it is suspected to have declined by at least 20% across its EU 27 range, and possibly 30% or more. It is therefore listed as Near Threatened approaching criteria A2cde and B1ab(iii,v).

Close monitoring and protection of the small remaining fragmented population is required to prevent local extinctions, particularly at the national levels where harvest and trade is carried out. Ex situ conservation in gene banks and increase in the area of cultivation to meet market demand should also be explored. It is strongly recommended to collect detailed population information and decline rates from each country and to re-assess the species when these data are available. It might then require a higher threat category.

Global and European regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)
EU 27 regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)

taxonomicnotes: Hunt et al. (2006) treat all of the other Galápagos Opuntia species as synonyms of this species, thus this is the one and only Opuntia species recognized as occurring on the Galápagos islands. All the species and varieties listed as synonyms were previously recognized as good taxa and assessed in 2000 for the IUCN Red List, but they are now all excluded as they are combined under this single species concept.
rationale: This species occurs across all of the Galápagos islands, it is common in some places, but some of the subpopulations (treated as varieties) are very scarce and have undergone significant reductions in the past due to the impacts of various threats, including feral animals and expanding agriculture and urbanization. However, overall the species as a whole is fairly common and is sufficiently secure on many of the islands and most of the threats identified are now largely past threats, hence it is listed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: This taxon was treated by Hunt et al. (2006) as a subspecies of P. bradyi, but it is widely accepted as a good species according to all North American floras and C.A. Butterworth (pers. comm.2010).
rationale: The species has very narrow range (extent of occurrence is 400 km<sup>2</sup>), is not abundant, it is threatened by illegal collection, however, the species is protected and has a recovery and management plan. Hence based on the species range it is listed as Near Threatened (almost qualifies for listing as threatened under criterion B1ab(v)).

taxonomicnotes: This taxon was treated by Hunt et al. (2006) as a subspecies of P. bradyi, but it is widely accepted as a good species according to all North American floras and C.A. Butterworth (pers. comm.).
rationale: The species has a narrow range, it occurs in a very isolated areas. The species has several protected and monitored populations. More subpopulations have been discovered in the last years which mitigates the threats. Therefore the species is listed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Hunt et al. (2006) treat P. desainii and P. winkleri as subspecies of P. bradyi, but these are widely accepted as being good species according to all North American floras and C.A. Butterworth (pers. comm.). They are considered separate species here.
rationale: The species is considered to be Near Threatened as it is close to qualifying for Vulnerable (B criteria). It occurs in a naturally small population (>300 individuals) where it is potentially threatened by future land use changes - thus requiring some level of management to avoid future extirpation. It has a narrow range, and even though there is some pressures on the population, it is locally protected and there is no evidence of rapid decline and its been managed by government agencies (Bureau of Land Management and US Fish and Wildlife Service).

Matucana pujupatii is reported from a very small area (extent of occurrence less than 100 km2), and it is known that it is sought after by collectors. However, it is not known whether this is causing a continuing decline in the population. The species is therefore listed as Near Threatened because if it is established that illegal collection is causing a continuing decline, it would qualify to be listed as Critically Endangered under Criterion B1ab(v).
evaluator: Goettsch, B.K., Superina, M. & Schipper, J.

taxonomicnotes: The morphology of this species is more similar to the genus Arrojadoa and it was originally described under that genus but recent molecular work has revealed that it belongs under the genus Micranthocereus and therefore it was moved there (Machado 2006). This species is most likely of intergeneric hybrid origin.
rationale: Micranthocereus hofackerianus has a restricted extent of occurrence (less than 5000 km2). It occurs at no more than five locations, and quarrying of sand is affecting the quality of its habitat. Fires are reducing its reproductive capacity, and the collection of seeds and whole plants for ornamental use is further reducing the populations. These threats are understood, but have not ceased and at least some of them are not reversible. The species is therefore listed as Endangered under criterion B.

taxonomicnotes: O. ammophila was described 1919 by J.K.Small and was placed in synonymy in O. humifusa by Benson (1982).  Work by Majure et al. in prep. supports the recognition of O. ammophila at the species level.
rationale: Opuntia ammophila is listed as Least Concern because it is very widespread within its range and occurs in protected areas.

taxonomicnotes: Texas Heritage questions the validity of this taxon.
rationale: Even though Opuntia aureispina has a limited range, its population is dense, there are no major threats, and it occurs within a protected area. Hence, it is listed as Least Concern.

Opuntia littoralis has a fairly wide range, and is considered a weed in places, so although there are threats to the habitat, these are not considered to be significant enough to warrant a threatened listing. The species is therefore listed as Least Concern.
assessor: Pinkava, D.J., Puente, R. & Baker, M.

rationale: Opuntia tehuantepecana is listed as Least Concern as it is relatively abundant within its limited range, tolerant to a degree of habitat modification, and occurs in protected areas.
assessor: Hernández, H.M., Gómez-Hinostrosa, C. & Cházaro, M.

rationale: Parodia turbinata has a wide range, a very large extent of occurrence, and it is locally abundant. There are threats in parts of its range but these mainly affect the subpopulation in Brazil. The species is here listed as Least Concern, nevertheless, in Brazil this cactus is suffering intense pressure and population declines have been observed; a regional assessment is thus recommended.
assessor: Larocca, J., Machado, M. & Duarte, W.

taxonomicnotes: Heil and Porter's treatment of Pediocactus in the Flora of North America (Vol. 4, 2003) recognizesPediocactus nigrispinus as a species, distinct from P. simpsonii. The text says, "Pediocactus nigrispinus has been referred to P. simpsonii var. robustior (J. M. Coulter) L. D. Benson, which remains well within the range of variation for P. simpsonii. An unpublished study by J. M. Porter et al. of noncoding chloroplast DNA sequences shows P. simpsonii is less closely related to P. nigripsinus than to P. knowltonii, P. winkleri, and P. despainii."
rationale: Pediocactus nigrispinus has a wide range, is locally abundant, and there are no major threats. Hence, it is listed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes:
According to Hunt et al. (2006) S. spinosior subsp. blainei  (S.L.Welsh & K.H.Thorne) Hochstätter should either be considered a separate species or S. pubispinus should also be included as a subspecies according to J. Porter and C. Butterworth (pers. comms.). However, the assessment is done including S. spinosior subsp. blainei .

The treatment followed in Kartesz (1999) excludes Sclerocactus sileri (formerly included in S. spinsior by Kartesz 1994); following this more narrow treatment, S. spinosior is endemic to Utah.
rationale: Sclerocactus spinosior has a relatively large range, is very abundant, and there are no overall threats to the species. Hence, it is listed as Least Concern.

The area of occupancy is estimated to be less than 500 km² (it is possibly even less than 10 km² but that would need to be confirmed), the two known localities are far apart and hence it is treated as severely fragmented and much of the area at the type locality is being developed as a residential centre. Hence is listed as Endangered. The population within the national park needs to be surveyed to determine its size, extent and any threats to it.

taxonomicnotes: Hunt et al. (2006) treat this as an enigmatic taxon.
rationale: This species has a narrow range (extent of occurrence is approximately 1,000 km<sup>2</sup>). There is an estimated 25% population reduction in the last 8 years and this is very likely to reach 30% in the next four years if the threats continue to affect the population in the same way. The species has a generation length of four years (to first flower). Hence it is listed as Vulnerable.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as a valid species by cactus specialists, Anderson (2001), Hunt (1999) and Pilbeam (1999).
rationale: Mammillaria albiflora is listed as Critically Endangered due to its very restricted range (extent of occurrence and area of occupancy less than 5 km²), its occurrence in a single location, and a continuing population decline as a result of illegal collecting that is also reducing its range. Its population has been diminished by an estimated 50% over the past 20 years, and the decline in mature individuals is continuing. Although a portion of the site has recently been enclosed with a chain link fence to protect it, this did not prevent access to the site.
assessor: Fitz Maurice, B, Fitz Maurice, W.A., Sánchez , E., Guadalupe Martínez, J. & Bárcenas Luna, R.

rationale: Cypripedium himalaicum is a very rare species, known only from a few scattered subpopulations (now severely fragmented), mostly in very small colonies, the area of occupancy of the species is about 110 km2 and the number of mature individuals is less than 250. The species is under numerous threats especially overgrazing, ruthless collection, habitat loss and disturbance of its restricted range due to trampling, deforestation, clear-cutting, logging practices and climate change which cause a continuing decline of the species in all the locations and the destruction of some subpopulations. Therefore, C. himalaicum is assessed as Endangered (EN).

As the habitat (near streams in grassland) in the largest part of its distribution area is declining in both extent and quality due to the suppression of regular burning and the discontinuing of grazing; and as one of the other locations is the scene of wholesale conversion to agriculture, we assess this taxon as Endangered.
assessor: IUCN SSC East African Plants Red List Authority

rationale: Cypripedium tibeticum is a local species with a scattered populations, mostly in small colonies but sometimes with very large colonies. Although C. tibeticum is under numerous threats especially overgrazing, ruthless collection, habitat loss and disturbance of its restricted range due to trampling, deforestation, clear-cutting, logging practices and climate change, these threats are unlikely to cause the population to decline very quickly in the near future. Therefore given its wide range, C. tibeticum is assessed as Least Concern (LC).

Cypripedium tibeticum is a local species with a scattered populations, mostly in small colonies but sometimes with very large colonies. Although C. tibeticum is under numerous threats especially overgrazing, ruthless collection, habitat loss and disturbance of its restricted range due to trampling, deforestation, clear-cutting, logging practices and climate change, these threats are unlikely to cause the population to decline very quickly in the near future. Therefore given its wide range, C. tibeticum is assessed as Least Concern (LC).

taxonomicnotes:
Taxonomic issues regarding the position of Andrena fimbriata within the Andrena labialis group are treated by Schönitzer et al. (1995).

Warncke (1967) examined the type of this species. Most previous records belong to A. forsterella, A. variabilis or other species of the subgenus Holandrena.
rationale:
Global and European regional assessment: Data Deficient (DD)
EU 27 regional assessment: Data Deficient (DD)

Listed as Data Deficient due to the gaps in knowledge of population size, trends, general ecology and specific threats. Further surveys are necessary in south-eastern Europe in order to establish the actual status of this species throughout its range, based on updated data recorded from the field.

Cypripedium molle is a strict endemic of Mexico, very local with a restricted and scattered distribution. The area of occupancy for this species is relatively small at 160 km2, but there are at least 15 locations and the range is not severely fragmented. There are numerous threats especially lopping of trees, deforestation, clear-cutting, random cutting of wood, overgrazing pressure, collection by local people with an estimated continuing decline in the quality of the habitats and possibly some localized declines in the species. The population trend overall though is thought to be stable at present. Although the area of occupancy of the species falls within the threshold of a threatened category, and there are some threats which may be causing localized declines, the number of locations exceeds the thresholds and the population is not severely fragmented. C. molle therefore qualifies for listing as Near Threatened (NT) as it almost meets the requirements for listing under criterion B2ab(iii).
Endemic to Lake Tanganyika where it is widespread throughout the littoral zone. It has no known major widespread threats although it may be locally threatened by siltation.
evaluator: Snoeks, J. (Freshwater Fish Red List Authority) & Darwall, W. (Freshwater Biodiversity Assessment Programme)

rationale: Cypripedium farreri is a very rare and local species, uncommon with a scattered distribution and extremely difficult to find and to access, the population trend is decreasing due to many threats and the area of occupancy of the species is only about 120 km2. The species is under numerous threats especially recent earthquakes, collection, habitat loss and disturbance, trampling, deforestation and infrastructure development which cause a continuing decline of the species and the quality of the habitats at the four known locations. The species therefore qualifies for listing as Endangered (EN).
Listed as Vulnerable as the species is known only from one locality.
assessor: Kerbis Peterhans, J., Taylor, P. & Maree, S. (GMA Africa Workshop)
evaluator: Amori, G. & Schlitter, D. (Rodent Red List Authority)

taxonomicnotes: This species was previously a synonym of O. tropicalis but is now recognised as distinct by Musser and Carleton 2005.
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient as this species has only just been removed from synonymy and it is still very confused taxonomically. There is no way to determine the extent of occurrence, population status or habitat requirements to enable an assessment.
assessor: Taylor, P. & Maree, S. (GMA Africa Workshop)
evaluator: Amori, G. & Schlitter, D. (Rodent Red List Authority)

taxonomicnotes: This species was included in O. typus but was recognised as distinct by Musser and Carleton (2005).
rationale: Listed as Endangered as it has an extent of occurrence less than 5,000 km², its distribution is severely fragmented, and there is burning of the species habitat that causes large fluctuations in the species' area of occupancy and the number of mature individuals.
assessor: Taylor, P., Maree, S. & Chitaukali, W. (GMA Africa Workshop)
evaluator: Amori, G. & Schlitter, D. (Rodent Red List Authority)

rationale: Cypripedium macranthos is widespread and common in some places where it occurs. The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of C. macranthos has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to numerous threats especially exploitation for horticultural and medicinal purposes, ruthless collection, trampling, weak recovery, frequent fires, overgrazing pressure, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy of the species are well above 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2, respectively. Because of its wide range the risk of extinction is low as the existing threats to the species and its habitats are unlikely to cause the population to decline quickly in the near future, especially if the conservation measures suggested are applied, raise public awareness and keep the existing conservations measures in place. Therefore, C. macranthos is assessed as Least Concern.

Cypripedium macranthos is widespread and common in some places where it occurs. The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of C. macranthos has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to numerous threats especially exploitation for horticultural and medicinal purposes, ruthless collection, trampling, weak recovery, frequent fires, overgrazing pressure, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy of the species are well above 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2, respectively. Therefore, C. macranthos is assessed as Least Concern.

The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of C. macranthos has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to numerous threats especially exploitation for horticultural and medicinal purposes, ruthless collection, trampling, weak recovery, frequent fires, overgrazing pressure, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism and infrastructure development.
