Cypripedium formosanum is rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in Taiwan. The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during the recent decades due to many threats especially  exploitation for horticultural and medicinal purposes, ruthless collection, trampling, recreation, rapid fires, overgrazing pressure, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and estimated area of occupancy of the species are below 5,000 km2 and 500 km2, respectively with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in the remaining five locations. Therefore, C. formosanum is assessed as Endangered (EN)

Cypripedium forrestii is rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution to northwest Yunnan, China and may possibly occur in adjacent Myanmar. The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, ecological disturbance, deforestation, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and estimated area of occupancy of the species are 350 km2 and 100 km2, respectively with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in the single location. Therefore, C. forrestii is assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium forrestii is rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution to northwest Yunnan, China and may possibly occur in adjacent Myanmar. The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, ecological disturbance, deforestation, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and estimated area of occupancy of the species are 350 km2 and 100 km2, respectively with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in the single location. Therefore, C. forrestii is assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium franchetii is rare and local with a scattered and restricted distribution to China. The trend of the population is decreasing and the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during the recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, recreation, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development.  The estimated area of occupancy of the species is about 150 km2 with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in all five known locations. Therefore, C. franchetii is assessed as Endangered (EN).

taxonomicnotes: This species used to be considered as a subspecies of Alticus kirkii; it is now known as a distinct species (J.T. Williams pers comm. 2009).
rationale: This is a fairly widespread species that is locally abundant with no known threats and is found in marine protected areas in parts of its range. It is listed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood. It is probably a local variant only and is closely related to Hylaeus hyalinatus.
rationale: Listed as Data Deficient in view of the lack of information on the species' population size, trends, habitat, ecological requirements and threats. Research should be conducted to assess the status of this species.
evaluator: Roberts, S., Nieto, A. & Scott, J.A.

rationale: Cypripedium calcicola is rare and very localized with a scattered and restricted distribution to northwesternYunnan, Sichuan and Shaanxi, China. The trend of the population is decreasing, the number of mature individuals is low and the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated area of occupancy of the species is between 136 and 250 km2 with an estimated continuing decline in the range, the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in the three locations. Therefore, C. calcicola is assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium fargesii is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in south Gansu, west Sichuan, west Hubei and north Chong, China.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often forming very small colonies, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during the recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated area of occupancy of the species is only 100 km2, the number of mature individuals is believed to be less than 250, with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in all four locations. The species is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium fargesii is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in south Gansu, west Sichuan, west Hubei and north Chong, China.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often forming very small colonies, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during the recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated area of occupancy of the species is only 100 km2, the number of mature individuals is believed to be less than 250, with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in all four locations. The species is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium lichiangense is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution to southwest Sichuan and northwest Yunnan in China and northeast Myanmar.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during the recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development.

The estimated area of occupancy of the species is about 250 km2, the number of mature individuals is low with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in the three locations. The species is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium sichuanense is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in northwest Sichuan in China.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The number of mature individuals is under 250, the estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy of the species are below 2,500 km2 and 70 km2 respectively (well below the thresholds for Endangered), with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in the two locations. The species therefore qualifies for listing as Endangered (EN).

taxonomicnotes: The species was formerly considered as a subspecies of O. cecilia. It is regarded now as a good species.
rationale: The species appears to be reasonably common within its its range and there are no indications of a decline. The species seems to have profited from the construction of irrigation channels which allowed the species to expand its range.

taxonomicnotes: The species named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists of Threatened Species was in fact Hylarana nicobariensis. The true Fejervarya nicobariensis was inadvertently omitted from the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists. The validity of the species was affirmed by Dubois and Ohler (2000).
rationale: Listed as Endangered because its Extent of Occurrence is less than 5,000 km2, its distribution is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.

Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of human-modified habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
evaluator: Global Amphibian Assessment Coordinating Team (Simon Stuart, Janice Chanson and Neil Cox)

rationale:
Cypripedium wardii is rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution to the southeast Xizang, west Sichuan and northwest Yunnan in China.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species occurs as solitary plants or in small groups, the total number of mature individuals is estimated to be less than 2,500 with extreme fluctuations and the abundance of the species was significantly reduced during the recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated area of occupancy of the species of 250 km2 is below 500 km2 threshold, the number of mature individuals is low with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of habitats in the three locations. Therefore, C. wardii is assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium shanxiense is rare and local with a scattered and restricted distribution to China, Japan and Russia.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in small colonies, the abundance of the species is significantly reduced due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recreation, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development.

The estimated extent of occurrence and the estimated area of occupancy of the species are greater than 20,000 km2 and 2,000 km2 respectively, the number of mature individuals is low with an inferred continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in its locations. The species does not qualify for listing as threatened under any of the thresholds, but the estimated area of occupancy of the species (2,232 km2) is close to the threatened threshold and because there are continuing declines we assessed Cypripedium shanxiense as Near Threatened (NT). It almost qualifies for listing under criterion B2ab(ii,iii,v).

Cypripedium yatabeanum is rare and local with a scattered (severely fragmented) and restricted distribution to China, USA and Russia.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species occurs as solitary plants or in small colonies, and the abundance of the species is significantly reduced due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recreation, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence  of the species is considerably in excess of the  greater than 20,000 km2 threshold  but the and the estimated area of occupancy is 2,500 km2 just a bit larger than the  2,000 km2 threshold, the number of mature individuals is low with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in its many locations. The species does not qualify for the threatened thresholds, but since the species is rare with a low number of mature individuals, under many threats and the estimated area of occupancy of the species is near the threatened threshold, we assess C. yatabeanum as Near Threatened (NT) (it almost qualifies for listing under criterion B2ab(ii,ii,v)).

Cypripedium segawae is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in northeast Taiwan. The population is declining, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species was significantly reduced during recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of the species are both 8 km2, with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in the single location. The species is therefore assessed as Critically Endangered (CR).

Cypripedium segawae is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in northeast Taiwan. The population is declining, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species was significantly reduced during recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of the species are both 8 km2, with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in the single location. The species is therefore assessed as Critically Endangered (CR).

Cypripedium ludlowii is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution in northwest Sichuan, southeast Xizang and west Yunnan in China.

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticulture and infrastructure development.

The number of mature individuals is under 250, the estimated area of occupancy of the species is about 200 km2, with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in all three of the known locations. The species is therefore assessed as Endangered (EN).

Cypripedium froschii is very rare and very local with a scattered and restricted distribution to northwestern Yunnan in China. The population is decreasing, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced during recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, weak recovery, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural and infrastructure development. The estimated extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of the species are both about 8 km2 and the number of mature individuals is estimated to be fewer than 50 in one subpopulation, with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in the single location. The species therefore qualifies for listing as Critically Endangered (CR).

Alnus rhombifolia is a commonly occurring species in the western United States. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect white alder in the foreseeable future. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.

Alnus rubra is a commonly occurring species in North America. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. This species is listed as Globally Secure (G5) on NatureServe. It is assessed here as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Alnus serrulata was erroneously called A . rugosa in a number of earlier floristic works (J. K. Small 1903, 1933; N. L. Britton and A. Brown 1896, 1913; B. L. Robinson and M. L. Fernald 1908), and the mistake was perpetuated in both editions of Flora Europaea (T. G. Tutin et al. 1964-1980, vol. 1; 1993+, vol. 1).
rationale: Alnus serrulata has a very broad geographic distribution in eastern North America. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. NatureServe ranks this species as globally secure (G5). It is assessed here as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: Ashburner and McAllister (2013) have placed Betula nana ssp. exilis in synonymy with Betula glandulosa.
rationale: Betula glandulosa is a very common species throughout a very large geographic range. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. NatureServe (2013) ranks this species as secure (G5T5). This species is assessed as Least Concern.

This species is listed as Least Concern, since it has not been declining by more than 25% in the last ten years, its European extent of occurrence (EOO) is larger than 20,000km² and its population size is probably larger than 10,000 adult individuals.
assessor: van Swaay, C., Wynhoff, I., Verovnik, R., Wiemers, M., López Munguira, M., Maes, D., Sasic, M., Verstrael, T., Warren, M. & Settele, J.
evaluator: Lewis, O. (Butterfly RLA) & Cuttelod, A. (IUCN Red List Unit)

taxonomicnotes: Ashburner and McAllister (2013) have combined Betula nana ssp. exilis into Betula glandulosa. The authors state “We interpret the material traditionally referred to B. nana ssp. exilis as dwarf, mainly more northern, variants of B. glandulosa”. This assessment follows the taxonomy of Ashburner and McAllister (2013).
rationale: Betula nana is a characteristic, commonly occurring species of Arctic and alpine tundra and subalpine moorlands and bogs throughout its very broad range of distribution. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes:
The Flora of North America in their treatment of Ostrya chisosensis states that this species appears to be related to O. knowltonii.  NatureServe is using a place holder name, Ostrya virginiana var. 1 awaiting the publication of Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis _____.  ITIS (2013) relates that the trinomial Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis (Correll) Henrickson ined. was apparently never published.

Ostrya chisosensis Correll is the accepted name. (PLANTS, 2013; Plant List, 2013, Tropicos, 2013).
rationale:
Ostrya chisosensis is known from eight occurrences in Big Bend National Park in Texas. During the Pliocene/Pleistocene era, the Arcto-tertiary geoflora extended southward in to the mountains of the American southwest and adjacent Mexico. As the Pleistocene Era came to a close the climate became warmer and drier. Tree taxa such as Ostrya knowltonii and O. chisosensis became restricted to canyons, occurring in the understory of oak (Quercus) and pine (Pinus) woodlands along streams and on adjacent moist slopes. As such, these two taxa are to be considered glacial relicts restricted to these canyons as well as reproductively isolated.

Ostrya chisosensis qualifies for the status of Critically Endangered under B1a and B1b.  The extent of occurrence is 20.5 km2. The eight subpopulations occur in eight geographically separated canyons and are reproductively isolated. The eight canyons are heavily timbered. Catastrophic wildfire has been identified as being able to affect any and/or all eight subpopulations. The overstory vegetation in the canyons is oak-pine and is subject to very intense wildfires. The climate in the southwestern United States is becoming drier and warmer. It can be inferred under these conditions that the chance of intense or catastrophic wildfires is greatly increased, especially in the next 150 years. Besides wildfire, there is a high probability that the current plant communities in these canyons will change with the potential loss of the oak pine overstory and the concurrent loss of moist slopes and stream side habitats leading to the loss of the species to taxa adapted to drier and warmer climate. The changing climate is also likely to increase the threat from insect and disease. It also qualifies for the status of Critically Endangered under B2a and B2b. The area of occupancy is 4.0 km2.

Betula populifolia is a very common species in the northeastern portion of its geographic range. At the southern and western portions of its range it occurs as disjunct populations in Indiana, West Virginia and Virginia. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. It is assessed as Least Concern.

Betula populifolia is a very common species in the northeastern portion of its geographic range. At the southern and western portions of its range it occurs as disjunct populations in Indiana, West Virginia and Virginia. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: None.
rationale: There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect Corylus americana in the foreseeable future. Climate change will extirpate it at its westernmost distribution. This will be offset with its northern range limits expanding further north in Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and east into the maritime provinces in Canada. In the southern Appalachian Mountains it will move up in elevation. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: None.
rationale: There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect Corylus americana in the foreseeable future. Climate change will extirpate it at its westernmost distribution. This will be offset with its northern range limits expanding further north in Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and east into the maritime provinces in Canada. In the southern Appalachian Mountains it will move up in elevation. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: None.
rationale: There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect Corylus americana in the foreseeable future. Climate change will extirpate it at its westernmost distribution. This will be offset with its northern range limits expanding further north in Manitoba, Ontario, Quebec and east into the maritime provinces in Canada. In the southern Appalachian Mountains it will move up in elevation. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: There continues to be some debate on the acceptance of subspecific taxa in Ostrya virginiana. In this assessment for Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis Flora Mesoamericanan, Tropicos and Govaerts state that Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis is the accepted name. Nelson Sutherland (2008) and Berendsohn, Gruber, and Salmon (2009) do not recognize the subspecific taxon Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis and identifies this taxon as Ostrya virginiana.
rationale: The federal governments of El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico have official lists (all published in 2006 or later) of threatened and endangered species. Mexico lists Ostrya virginiana (Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis) as “subject to special protection”.  El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras do not include Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis on their respective list of threatened or endangered species. The Red List of Mexican Cloud Forest Trees assesses Ostrya virginiana (Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis) as Near Threatened. The Red List of Trees of Guatemala does not include Ostrya virginiana ssp. guatemalensis as threatened. Therefore, this taxon is assessed as Least Concern but it is recommend that it be re-examined again in 10 years.

taxonomicnotes: There continues to be some debate on the acceptance of Carpinus tropicalis as opposed to Carpinus caroliniana as it exists in MesoAmerica. Furlow (1987) accepted Carpinus tropicalis as the accepted name and also recognized two subspecies, Carpinus tropicalis ssp. tropicalis and Carpinus tropicalis ssp. mexicana. Furlow (1987) delimited the range of Carpinus caroliniana ssp. caroliniana to the eastern United States. Flora MesoAmerica (Davidse et al. 2013), Tropicos, Kew’s World Checklist, Flora de Nicaragua (Furlow 2009) and Berendsohn, Gruber and Salmon (2009) state that Carpinus tropicalis is the accepted name of the species that occurs in cloud forests from souther Mexico into Guatemala. N. Sutherland (2008), however, does not recognize Carpinus tropicalis and identifies this taxon as Carpinus caroliniana. The Red List of Mexican Cloud Forest Trees (2011) lists Carpinus caroliniana as Near Threatened, but the information correlates with Carpinus tropicalis.
rationale: The federal governments of El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico have official lists (all published in 2006 or later) of threatened and endangered species.  Mexico lists Carpinus caroliniana (Carpinus tropicalis) as “subject to special protection”. El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras do not include this species on their respective list of threatened or endangered species. The Red List of Mexican Cloud Forest Trees assesses lists Carpinus caroliniana (assessed as Carpinus tropicalis) as Near Threatened. The Red List of Trees of Guatemala does not include it as threatened. Therefore, this taxon is assessed as Least Concern but it is recommended that it be re-examined again in 10 years.

This species is listed as globally secure by NatureServe. It is a widespread, commonly encountered tree of eastern North America and Canada. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. This species is therefore not considered to be threatened. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes:
The tetraploid B. cylindrostachya is a member of sub genus Acuminatae and closely related to the diploid B. alnoides and B. luminifera, with which it has been confused. It can be distinguished from B.alnoides by its spring rather than autumn-winter flowering period, its wider fruiting catkins and more cordate leaf bases. Some material in cultivation introduced as B. alnoides is probably B. cylindrostachya (Ashburner and McAllister 2013). Betula luminifera is morphologically very similar, but has (usually) solitary female catkins (catkins are in groups of two to six in the other two species).


The recently described B. fujianensis would seem from its description to be synonymous with B. cylindrostachya, the only significant difference being the glandular shoots and the absence of hair tufts in the secondary vein axils on the abaxial leaf surface.

Betula rhombibracteata is doubtfully distinct from B. cylindrostachya
rationale: This species has a wide distribution and is common across its range. There are no reported major threats to this species. Betula cylindrostachya is therefore assessed as Least Concern. In the Chinese Red List this species is also assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes:
Betula tatewakiana is generally considered a minor variant of B. fruticosa

Betula baicalensis is a possible hybrid between B. fruticosa and B. pendula

Betula middendorfii and B. divaricata probably belong here, but are very similar to B. glandulosa from Goose Bay in Labrador
rationale: In the Chinese Red List this species is assessed as Least Concern. This species is assessed as Vulnerable in Japan under the synonym Betula ovalifolia. This species is therefore considered locally threatened in Japan, but due to its wider distribution outside of Japan, where it is reported to be common with no major threats, it is not considered to be globally threatened. It is therefore assessed here as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: Ashburner and McAllister (2013) have placed Betula nana ssp. exilis in synonymy with Betula glandulosa.
rationale: Betula glandulosa is a very common species throughout a very large geographic range. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. NatureServe (2013) ranks this species as secure (G5T5). This species is assessed as Least Concern.

This orchid has suffered declines in subpopulations due to habitat loss and collection for its medicinal and horticultural use. It is classified as Vulnerable in Sri Lanka and is thought to be rapidly declining in parts of India where a preliminary assessment has classified it as Critically Endangered in Madya Pradesh. There is no information on the population in Myanmar, Nepal or Bangladesh. Based on collection records it has a widespread distribution,with an extent of occurrence (EOO) that greatly exceeds the value for a threatened category. No numerical population data is available. There have undoubtedly been population declines, but, as it is reported as abundant and common in parts of its range, it is suspected that the declines in the overall population are not sufficient to meet the criteria for a threatened category under criterion A. It is assessed as Least Concern, however, further surveys are needed to establish the current habitat and population status and monitoring is needed to enumerate declines.
evaluator: Gunasekara, S., Huda, M.K., Pant, B. & Kumar, C.S.

taxonomicnotes: The status of B. halophila, a species previously listed as threatened, is uncertain. Although its unique habitat for a birch suggests that it may be genetically distinct from any other birch, it is not easily distinguishable morphologically. It is a probable synonym of B. microphylla
rationale: This species has a wide range, with no reported threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: Betula kenaica is said to differ from B. papyrifera primarily in its smaller stature and in its smaller, blunter-tipped, more coarsely and regularly serrate leaves. It is best considered a westward extension of B. papyrifera into southern Alaska, perhaps affected by introgression from B. pendula ssp. mandshurica.
rationale:
Betula papyrifera is a widespread, commonly encountered tree of mixed hardwood/conifer forest ecosystems throughout Canada and the northern United States extending southward in the Appalachian Mountains where it is a component of high elevational spruce/fir forests. It is a common species occurring in nearly 40 northern forest types. In east and east-central Canada and United States it is a major component of two forest cover types: Paper Birch and Paper Birch-Red Spruce-Balsam Fir. In Alaska and western Canada paper birch is a major component three forest cover types: Black Spruce-Paper Birch, White Spruce-Paper Birch and Paper Birch.

There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect paper birch in the foreseeable future. Climate change will extirpate paper birch at its southernmost distribution. Especially in the mid to southern Appalachian Mountains but this may be offset with its northern range limits expanding in Quebec and Ontario, Canada. It is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: This species has a morphologically distinct 6x cytotype known only from two high mountains in South Korea whose conservation status is uncertain. The species otherwise is 8x which is common. Until more collections of both types have been checked and compared, and a geographical difference has emerged, the two types do not merit different names.
rationale: This species is common across its distribution and there are no known threats that are or will adversely effect the species in the foreseeable future. In the   Chinese Red List this species is assessed as Least Concern. This species is assessed here as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes:
Betula dahurica occurs as two cytotypes, which are rather similar to one another. The octoploid cytotype is common and widespread in continental northeastern Asia including Korea, but the hexaploid is rare and found in Japan and the Kurile Island of Iturup.

It has been proposed by Ashburner and McAllister (2013) that the continental octoploid cytotype is recognised as var. dahurica, the Kurile Island and Hokkaido populations as var. okuboi, and the more distinct Honshu populations as var. parvifolia.
rationale: This species has a wide distribution and no known major threats. It is listed as Least Concern in the Chinese Red List and is therefore assumed not to be threatened. Betula dahurica is assessed as Vulnerable in Japan, but due to its wide global distribution it is considered to be locally threatened in Japan, but not globally threatened. It is assessed here as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale:
This species has a wide but patchy distribution and has a reducing population across its range, which is likely to continue to decline if additional conservation measures are not put in place. It is now rare in Western Europe, has only a few locations reported in Germany, is scarce in Poland where it appears to be absent from formerly recorded sites, and is thought to be extinct in the Czech Republic where it has not been seen for at least 50 years. Populations are reported to be rare in Austria, Vulnerable in Romania and Critically Endangered in Switzerland.

Betula humilis is found growing on open raised bogs and pine moors, acid valley bogs, drained fens, transitional mires and in open birch woodlands. This species has declined over past centuries due to the advance of cultivation and the drainage of bogs. This may be exacerbated by competition with Salix species and shading by brushwood from overgrowing shrub and forest.

The threats facing this species are not likely to cease, therefore depending on current area of occupancy, this species could qualify as Vulnerable under criterion A due to its reduced population. However, due to a lack of data on population reductions, we are unable to specify a threat category or Near Threatened category. Further study is needed to better quantify the population size reduction.

The fact that this species has declined across its range and become locally extinct in the Czech Republic means that conservation action is a high priority for this species, at least in parts of its range.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes:
Betula utilis, B. jacquemontii and B. albosinensis, are clearly closely related, and have been recognised in the past as separate species, subspecies or varieties. All are tetraploid and, although the extremes are very different, it is often difficult to distinguish between them. They are here treated as subspecies of B. utilis: B. utilis ssp. utilis, B. utilis ssp. jacquemontii and B. utilis ssp. albosinensis

Betula jinpingensis is doubtfully distinct from B. utilis.
rationale: This species has a wide distribution and is common. However, it is exploited for its medicinal uses and over exploitation is particularly high in parts of its range. It is not thought that these threats are large enough to impact upon the species across its whole range. In the   Chinese Red List (2014) this species is assessed as Least Concern. It is assessed here as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species has a fairly wide distribution. There are no known threats impacting the survival of this species. The Chinese Red List assesses this species as Least Concern. It is assessed here as Least Concern on the basis of its distribution and lack of known threats.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: Carpinus tientaiensis is assessed as Critically Endangered, occurring in a single location with a very small area of occupancy and extent of occurrence, with a low population number. A decline in the area, extent and quality of habitat is also observed and predicted to continue. This species is also assessed as Critically Endangered in the Chinese Red List. The observed population decline is due to deforestation and conversion of land to monoculture plantations of bamboo and tea. These threats persist in the area. There are only 21 mature individuals in the wild.  The small population makes this species susceptible to stochastic events and competition from fast growing species also presents a threat. Conservation of this species should be a priority.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species is fairly widespread. In the   Chinese Red List (2014) this species is assessed as Least Concern. Much of the distributional range of this species is within China and it is therefore assumed not to be threatened.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species has a fairly wide distribution in China and has no reported major threats. In the   Chinese Red List (2014) this species is assessed as Least Concern. It is also assessed here as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species has a fairly wide distribution. In the   Chinese Red List (2014) this species is assessed as Least Concern. Much of the distributional range of this species is within China and it is therefore not considered to be threatened.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, since it has not been declining by more than 25% in the last ten years, its European extent of occurrence (EOO) is larger than 20,000km² and its population size is probably larger than 10,000 adult individuals.
assessor: van Swaay, C., Wynhoff, I., Verovnik, R., Wiemers, M., López Munguira, M., Maes, D., Sasic, M., Verstrael, T., Warren, M. & Settele, J.
evaluator: Lewis, O. (Butterfly RLA) & Cuttelod, A. (IUCN Red List Unit)

taxonomicnotes: This skipper used to be considered a sub-species of the Red-underwing Skipper (S. sertorius).
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, since it has not been declining by more than 25% in the last ten years and its population size is probably larger than 10,000 adult individuals.
assessor: van Swaay, C., Wynhoff, I., Verovnik, R., Wiemers, M., López Munguira, M., Maes, D., Sasic, M., Verstrael, T., Warren, M. & Settele, J.
evaluator: Lewis, O. (Butterfly RLA) & Cuttelod, A. (IUCN Red List Unit)

rationale: This species has a wide distribution and is reported to be common across the majority of its range. There are no major threats reported for this species. It is therefore not considered to be threatened and is evaluated as Least Concern. In the   Chinese Red List this species is also assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: Carpinus caroliniana consists of two rather well-marked geographical races, treated here as subspecies. These hybridize or intergrade in a band extending from Long Island along the Atlantic coast through coastal Virginia and North Carolina, and then westward in northern South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana. Plants with intermediate features are also found throughout the highlands of Missouri and Arkansas. J. J. Furlow (1987b) has described the variation of this complex in detail.
rationale: NatureServe ranks this species as globally secure, however the subpopulation in Quebec is Vulnerable. This species has a wide distribution and is common across much of its range. It is not considered to be globally threatened and is therefore assessed here as Least Concern.
assessor: Stritch, L., Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with large subpopulations in the United States of America and Canada. Although local deforestation is impacting cloud forest populations in Mexico and Central America, thereby reducing the extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO) and population size, overall this species is still not approaching thresholds for it to be considered threatened. It is therefore evaluated globally as Least Concern, but conservation actions are recommended for southern subpopulations.
assessor: Stritch, L., Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with large subpopulations in the United States of America and Canada. Although local deforestation is impacting cloud forest populations in Mexico and Central America, thereby reducing the extent of occurrence (EOO), area of occupancy (AOO) and population size, overall this species is still not approaching thresholds for it to be considered threatened. It is therefore evaluated globally as Least Concern, but conservation actions are recommended for southern subpopulations.
assessor: Stritch, L., Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale:
Cypripedium lentiginosum is very rare and local with a scattered and restricted distribution to southeastern Yunnan in China and Ha Giang province in Viet Nam. 

The trend of the population is decreasing, the species often occurs as solitary plants or in very small groups, the abundance of the species has been significantly reduced in recent decades due to many threats especially collection, trampling, ecological disturbance, deforestation, tourism, exploitation for horticultural uses and infrastructure development.

The estimated extent of occurrence and area of occupancy of the species are about 50 km2 and 20 km2 respectively and the number of mature individuals is less than 100 with an estimated continuing decline in the number of mature individuals and the quality of the habitats in the two known locations. Therefore, C. lentiginosum is assessed as Endangered (EN).

taxonomicnotes: Trisopterus capelanus was previously considered the Mediterranean sub-species of T. minutus (T. m. capelanus) and has since been elevated to the status of a fully valid species (Mattiangeli et al. 2000, Delling et al. 2011, Gonzalez et al. 2012).
rationale: Trisopterus capelanus is restricted to the Mediterranean Sea, where it is one of the most abundant endemic species. There is no known large-scale fishery for T. capelanus, although it is harvested in some regions as a food source and it is a bycatch of trawl and purse seine fisheries. It occurs at depths ranging from zero to 450 meters, but is more abundant at depths of 50 to 150 metres with a preferences for mixed sand and mud bottoms. Monitoring of the harvest levels and population numbers of this species is needed, so that any change in the levels of exploitation can be noted. Fishing mortality, both direct and indirect, is not thought to be a major threat at this time and there are no other known widespread threats. This entirety of the depth range and the preferred habitat of this species (sandy-muddy bottoms) are accessible to trawling. Trisopterus capelanus has become a major commercial species and has been increasingly exploited since the late 1980s. Once exclusively considered a bycatch species, it is now targeted in parts of its range, particularly in the eastern Mediterranean and the Catalan coast. Mediterranean fisheries are characterized as multi-species fisheries, and in addition to being directly targeted this species is retained as bycatch, particularly in Hake and Red Mullet fisheries, both of which are considered largely overexploited throughout the region. Overexploitation of T. capelanus has been observed as early as 1988, in the Straits of Sicily. In the Adriatic Sea T. capelanus is also experiencing high fishing pressure, which has caused significant reductions in total length (maximum observed size of 21.5 cm, vs. maximum recorded size of 32 cm) and a low proportion of specimens older than three years old catches. This species has a maximum observed age of six years and is likely sexually mature by ages one to two, however age of first maturity has not been confirmed. The overall trend in landings declared to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is one of gradual increase to a peak of 3,290 tonnes in 2006. From 2006 to 2001, landings declined by 46% to 1,751 tonnes. There is little biological information available and stock assessments are not performed on this species. It appears to be experiencing localized overfishing in parts of its range, however there is not currently enough information available to characterize the status of the population throughout its range. Therefore, T. capelanus is assessed as Least Concern.

taxonomicnotes: This taxon was considered a subspecies of Nycticebus coucang but elevated by Groves and Maryanto (2008). This is further supported by morphological studies by Nekaris and Jaffe (2007) and Nekaris and Munds (2010) and genetic studies by Roos (2003) and Wirdateti et al. (2006). Two distinct forms regularly occur in bird markets and further research is needed (Nekaris and Jaffe 2007). Care should be taken in taxonomic studies however due to translocation of individuals from markets into forests and gardens throughout the island (Schulze and Groves 2004). The distinct black and white long-haired appearance of subadults and juveniles also might be mistaken as separate species, for example, in museum specimens or from photos only (A. Nekaris et al. pers. comm. 2012).
rationale: This species is listed as Critically Endangered based on a combination of historic forest loss and continued degradation meaning that less than 20% of habitat suitable for N. javanicus remains. Species distribution modelling and a gap analysis have also revealed that the remaining subpopulations of N. javanicus are highly fragmented, with only 17% of the potential distribution within the protected area network (Thorn et al. 2009). Adding to this, the species has experienced a suspected decline of at least 80% over the last 24 years (equals three generations; Nadler et al . 2007) due to severe and persistent and ongoing persecution for the pet trade (Nekaris et al. 2010).
assessor: Nekaris, K.A.I. , Shekelle, M, Wirdateti, Rode, E.J. & Nijman, V.

taxonomicnotes: Accepted as Rhampholeon platyceps (Tilbury 2010). Populations of Rhampholeon on Mt. Chiperone, Mabu and Namuli are separate taxa and should not be confused with R. platyceps (Branch et al. 2014). In addition, molecular phylogenetic analysis shows that the sub-species, R. platyceps carri is not valid (Branch et al. 2014).
rationale: Rhampholeon platyceps is considered Endangered because it has a small Area of Occupancy and the threats to the montane forest habitat are tangible. It is estimated that up to a half of its habitat has already been lost, or is degraded. Therefore the population is inferred to have substantial undergone declines, is presently severely fragmented, the number of threat locations probably five or less, and threats are ongoing. There is concern that if the threats continue or escalate, the species will be subject to additional declines through further loss and fragmentation of habitat.

Listed as Vulnerable based on a projected 30% population reduction in the next 21 years (three generations) due to the continuing decline in the extent and quality of a key habitat (forest, which is relied upon for roosting and at certain times of year for foraging); knowledge of impacts of past cyclones on this and other island fruit bats and the likelihood of this happening again on Mauritius within the next few years; and based on current pressures from hunting, which are likely to increase.

taxonomicnotes: Thylamys pallidior consists of a single species with a broad distribution throughout the Arid Diagonal of southern South America (Bruniard 1982). Despite its extended distribution, morphologic and morphometric studies show no differentiation (Martin 2008). Molecular analyses (Braun et al. 2005, Giarla et al. 2010) show a separation between a northern and southern clade.The species Thylamys fenestrae has been recently split from this species based on morphological, morphometric and chromosomal differences with T. pallidior.
rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because of its wide distribution, presumed large population, occurrence in a number of protected areas, and because it is unlikely to be declining at nearly the rate required to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
assessor: Martin, G.M., Teta, P. & Albanese, M.S.

taxonomicnotes: Ashburner and McAllister (2013) have combined Betula nana ssp. exilis into Betula glandulosa. The authors state “We interpret the material traditionally referred to B. nana ssp. exilis as dwarf, mainly more northern, variants of B. glandulosa”. This assessment follows the taxonomy of Ashburner and McAllister (2013).
rationale: Betula nana is a characteristic, commonly occurring species of Arctic and alpine tundra and subalpine moorlands and bogs throughout its very broad range of distribution. There are no known threats that are or will adversely affect this species in the foreseeable future. It is assessed as Least Concern.
This subspecies has a fairly wide distribution with no known threats. It is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes:
Although there is great variation in habit and stature in the trees associated with different habitats there are no clear boundaries between the different forms. The most useful taxonomic treatment is to give names to the most distinct, but only at the varietal level. Therefore var. pubescens for the tall central European and souther British and Scandinavian populations, var. pumila for northern populations, whcih are probably derived from var. pubescens through adaptive selection and introgression from B. nana, var. fragrans for aromatic, small leaved trees from northwest Britain, and var. litwinowii for Anatolian and Caucasian populations which are probably largely the result of introgression from B. pendula

Betula coriacea and B. concinna from Sweden remain enigmantic, similar to one another, and distinct from other forms of B. pubescens

Betula turtuosa, B. borysthenica, B. kusmischeffii, B. rezniczenkoana, B. kelleriana, B. ircutensis and B. baicalensis await further study
rationale: Although locally rare and considered threatened in some areas (listed as Critically Endangered in Croatia, Vulnerable in Hungary and Bosnia and Herzegovina, Near Threatened in Luxembourg) it is considered to be of Least Concern over much of its range (including in Denmark, Estonia, Norway, Switzerland and Great Britain). The population of this species is declining in some areas, including southern Europe, due to a decline in peat bog habitats. However, given its widespread distribution, common occurrence throughout Europe, the presence of stable populations and the absence of major threats across much of its range, this species has been classified as Least Concern overall.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: Some specimens considered to be this species by Bradham et al. in 1983 might represent an undescribed taxon.
rationale: Aloe glabrescens is a widespread species in Somalia, although the local populations are small. The natural habitat of this species is very unfavourable for agricultural expansion which means there is a reduced risk to the species from land conversion to field. Herded animals may constitute a threat.

taxonomicnotes: Hybrids with A. amudatensis occur at Amudat.
rationale: Aloe tweedieae is widespread in southeastern Sudan, Kenya and Uganda. Real threats to the species exist in the form of habitat degradation and loss as well as harvest from the wild for medicinal purposes. It is not possible to assess the impact of these factors on local populations without further research. Given the large range of the species, it is listed as Least Concern for now.

This distribution of this taxon is uncertain. Within its range countries it is restricted to damp woods and river banks. Further research is needed to better determine the distribution and population status of this taxon so a full conservation assessment can be carried out. This taxon is currently assessed as Data Deficient.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: Chamaesyce remyi is endemic to the island of Kauai, Hawaii. The species occupies an area of less than 100 km². Habitat is fragmented and there is ongoing decline in habitat quality. The taxon is threatened by feral goats and pigs, deer and invasive alien plants.
evaluator: Maunder, M. (Plant Conservation Committee) & Pollock, C.M. (Red List Programme Office)

rationale: This species has a fairly wide range within Mexico, but its distribution is limited to areas along streams between 1,000-2,500 m asl. Limited information is currently available about this taxon and it is therefore assessed as Data Deficient. Further research is needed to determine the current distribution and population status of this taxon.
assessor: Stritch, L., Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

rationale: There is little information available about this taxon. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient and in need of further study.

taxonomicnotes: Closely related to B. pendula. It has been confused with B. mandshurica from northeast Asia and Japan. Was once designated as its own species, it is now accepted as a subspecies of B. pendula by Ashford.
rationale: This taxon is reported to have a fairly wide distribution, occurring across five states of China. It is recently described and no population information or detailed distribution is available for this species. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient. Additional field research is needed to determine distribution and population status to enable a full conservation assessment to be undertaken.
assessor: Shaw, K., Wilson, B. & Roy , S.

rationale: This taxon is cultivated as an ornamental and has long been a favourite in gardens and arboreta. The timber is used for firewood and the bark stripped for roofing. Further population information is required to ensure exploitation is not causing a population decline. It is assessed here as Data Deficient.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: Trees from the extremes of the distribution in Europe (Betula pendula), northeast Asia and Japan and western North America (B. platyphylla, B. mandshurica, B. neoalaskana) and southwest China and Tibet (B. szechuanica) look different and can be distinguished from one another. However, when the whole continuous geographical range of diploid silver birches is considered, all those named as species intergrade in geographically intervening areas. It is thought to be best divided into three subspecies, ssp. pendula in Europe and eastwards to central Asia, ssp. mandshurica in eastern Asia and western North America and ssp. szechuanica in western China from Qinghai and Gansu to Yunnan and southeast Xizang. Betula platyphylla has been described as a seperate species, representing birches from Mongolia east of the Altai and into western and northeastern China but it is thought the two are synonymous. Betula oycoviensis previously listed as threatened is a form of B. pendula. Betula pendula ssp. font-queri and B. pendula ssp. parvibracteata, previously listed as threatened are thought to be only minor variants of B. pendula. Betula szaferi, described previously as Extinct in the Wild, is now considered a weak growing, precociously and heavily fruiting form of B. pendula, due to the presence of a mutant gene
rationale: Betula pendula is classified as Least Concern due to its widespread distribution, stable populations and no major threats.
assessor: Stritch, L., Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: It might be questioned whether this taxon should be recognised as a distinct species. Its geographical isolated and the fact that it can be distinguished morphologically suggest that it is worth recognising. In Flora Iberica, Peinado and Mereno (1990) did not distinguish it from B. pubescens. However, it is equally out of place in B. pendula. In fact, it is probably most similar to another 'species' of stablised hybrid origin, the east North America B. x caerulea.
rationale: Other subpopulations of birch in isolated ranges in central Spain may belong to this species, but are thought more likely to be relict populations of B. pendula or B. pubescens. Further field research is needed to verify the distribution and population status of this species to enable a full conservation assessment. It is therefore assessed as Data Deficient.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes: Until recently B. cordifolia has been regarded as a variety, or a northerly or montane form of B. papyrifera. Furlow (1997) in the Flora of North America questions whether it deserves specific status. However, the studies of Brittain & Grant (1965b, 1967b) and Grant & Thompson (1975) confirmed the diploid status of B. cordifolia, defined its morphological distinctness, and suggest that it is likely to be one of the constituent genomes of hexaploid B. papyrifera. Reports of tetraploids in B. cordifolia are likely to be due to the great difficulty in distinguishing between B. cordiolia and the B. cordifolia x B. papyrifera hybrid.
rationale: This species has a fairly wide distribution and it is reported to be common across much of its distribution. In other parts of its distribution the species is less common, but there are no known major threats to this species. It is therefore not considered to be threatened and is evaluated as Least Concern.
assessor: Shaw, K., Roy , S. & Wilson, B.

taxonomicnotes:
A newly described combination by Ashburner & McAllister, 2013

Betula litwinowii is hardly distinguishable from B. pubescens var. litwinowii of the Swiss Jura or the Pyrenees. Betula recurvata, listed previously as threatened, differs mainly in its larger leaves and absence of resin glands and is probably a local variant.

The recently described B. browicziana which has in the past been listed as threatened, is thought to be a local variant
rationale: This is a newly described combination (Ashburner and McAllister 2013). There is little information available about this taxon and it is therefore assessed as Data Deficient and in need of further study.

taxonomicnotes:
The Flora of North America in their treatment of Ostrya chisosensis states that this species appears to be related to O. knowltonii.  NatureServe is using a place holder name, Ostrya virginiana var. 1 awaiting the publication of Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis _____.  ITIS (2013) relates that the trinomial Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis (Correll) Henrickson ined. was apparently never published.

Ostrya chisosensis Correll is the accepted name. (PLANTS, 2013; Plant List, 2013, Tropicos, 2013).
rationale:
Ostrya chisosensis is known from eight occurrences in Big Bend National Park in Texas. During the Pliocene/Pleistocene era, the Arcto-tertiary geoflora extended southward in to the mountains of the American southwest and adjacent Mexico. As the Pleistocene Era came to a close the climate became warmer and drier. Tree taxa such as Ostrya knowltonii and O. chisosensis became restricted to canyons, occurring in the understory of oak (Quercus) and pine (Pinus) woodlands along streams and on adjacent moist slopes. As such, these two taxa are to be considered glacial relicts restricted to these canyons as well as reproductively isolated.

Ostrya chisosensis qualifies for the status of Critically Endangered under B1a and B1b.  The extent of occurrence is 20.5 km2. The eight subpopulations occur in eight geographically separated canyons and are reproductively isolated. The eight canyons are heavily timbered. Catastrophic wildfire has been identified as being able to affect any and/or all eight subpopulations. The overstory vegetation in the canyons is oak-pine and is subject to very intense wildfires. The climate in the southwestern United States is becoming drier and warmer. It can be inferred under these conditions that the chance of intense or catastrophic wildfires is greatly increased, especially in the next 150 years. Besides wildfire, there is a high probability that the current plant communities in these canyons will change with the potential loss of the oak pine overstory and the concurrent loss of moist slopes and stream side habitats leading to the loss of the species to taxa adapted to drier and warmer climate. The changing climate is also likely to increase the threat from insect and disease. It also qualifies for the status of Critically Endangered under B2a and B2b. The area of occupancy is 4.0 km2.

taxonomicnotes:
The Flora of North America in their treatment of Ostrya chisosensis states that this species appears to be related to O. knowltonii.  NatureServe is using a place holder name, Ostrya virginiana var. 1 awaiting the publication of Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis _____.  ITIS (2013) relates that the trinomial Ostrya virginiana var. chisosensis (Correll) Henrickson ined. was apparently never published.

Ostrya chisosensis Correll is the accepted name. (PLANTS, 2013; Plant List, 2013, Tropicos, 2013).
rationale:
Ostrya chisosensis is known from eight occurrences in Big Bend National Park in Texas. During the Pliocene/Pleistocene era, the Arcto-tertiary geoflora extended southward in to the mountains of the American southwest and adjacent Mexico. As the Pleistocene Era came to a close the climate became warmer and drier. Tree taxa such as Ostrya knowltonii and O. chisosensis became restricted to canyons, occurring in the understory of oak (Quercus) and pine (Pinus) woodlands along streams and on adjacent moist slopes. As such, these two taxa are to be considered glacial relicts restricted to these canyons as well as reproductively isolated.

Ostrya chisosensis qualifies for the status of Critically Endangered under B1a and B1b.  The extent of occurrence is 20.5 km2. The eight subpopulations occur in eight geographically separated canyons and are reproductively isolated. The eight canyons are heavily timbered. Catastrophic wildfire has been identified as being able to affect any and/or all eight subpopulations. The overstory vegetation in the canyons is oak-pine and is subject to very intense wildfires. The climate in the southwestern United States is becoming drier and warmer. It can be inferred under these conditions that the chance of intense or catastrophic wildfires is greatly increased, especially in the next 150 years. Besides wildfire, there is a high probability that the current plant communities in these canyons will change with the potential loss of the oak pine overstory and the concurrent loss of moist slopes and stream side habitats leading to the loss of the species to taxa adapted to drier and warmer climate. The changing climate is also likely to increase the threat from insect and disease. It also qualifies for the status of Critically Endangered under B2a and B2b. The area of occupancy is 4.0 km2.

taxonomicnotes: A subspecies Palleon (formerly Brookesia) nasus pauliani is recognized from high-altitude sites at Andringtra, but it was not found during the most recent surveys and its taxonomic status remains unresolved (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996).
rationale: Listed as Vulnerable as the species has an estimated extent of occurrence of 15,798 km² in a region of southeast Madagascar where there is a continuing decline in the quality and extent of humid forest due to slash-and-burn agriculture, logging and mining, and it is thought to occur as a severely fragmented population.
assessor: Jenkins, R.K.B., Andreone, F., Andriamazava, A., Anjeriniaina, M., Brady, L., Glaw, F., Griffiths, R.A., Rabibisoa, N., Rakotomalala, D., Randrianantoandro, J.C., Randrianiriana, J., Randrianizahana , H., Ratsoavina, F. & Robsomanitrandrasana, E.

rationale: Calamagrostis inexpansa is rated as Least Concern due to its very large geographic range, low habitat specificity, occurrence within numerous protected areas and because it is reported as common and abundant in many parts of the range.
evaluator: Bennett, B., Fulkerson, J. & Heidel, B.

rationale: Carex rossii is very widely distributed, occurring in all the western parts of the USA and Canada and the large extent of occurrence (EOO) suggests it is not threatened. The taxon has been recently described as common and abundant in most of its range (specimen data, Ownbey and Morley 2005, Cole 2007, Jepson Flora Project 2008) and described as a dominant graminoid of the Pacific Northwest. Its occurrence being seemingly rarer east of the Rocky Mountains and in the upper Great Lakes region (Gerdes 2003). Carex rossii is locally rare and threatened in Ontario, Michigan, Nebraska, North Dakota, and Minnesota. Recent occurrences in New Mexico and Illinois have been reported where it is uncommon. Carex rossii occurs in 36 different ecoregions of Canada and the USA and is adapted to a wide range of habitats. Although there are general threats to plant species in these regions, these are not direct threats to C. rossii. The taxon is described as a strong competitor which thrives on hostile and disturbed sites and is a dominant understorey species in many communities where it occurs. Carex rossii is drought, trampling, browsing, and even oil spills tolerant and very hard to remove from places where it grows. The taxon is legally protected in Michigan, Nebraska and Ontario. where it is threatened and occurs in areas which benefit from some level of protection in all its range. Carex rossii was assessed as globally secure in the USA, by NatureServe, in 1988. There is no evidence to show that the status of the taxon has changed therefore C. rossii is assessed as Least Concern.
evaluator: Arnett, J., Bennett, B. & Heidel, B.

taxonomicnotes: This form is a complex of several species. G. piperata was recently separated out by Duellman and Köhler (2005). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.

taxonomicnotes: This name name probably covers more than one species (Schiøtz 1999). The population in western Kenya previously assigned to this species was recently described as a new species, Leptopelis mackayi (Köhler et al. 2006). It is possible that the populations in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo refer to L. mackayi, or to an undescribed species.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, its presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
assessor: Schiøtz, A., Amiet, J.-L. & Drewes, R.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

taxonomicnotes:
Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al., 2006). Additional analyses identify phenotypic
and genetic differentiation consistent with proposed Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs), and support the status of Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki as separate species (Richards and Knowles, 2007).
rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because of a drastic population decline, estimated to be more than 80% over the last three generations, inferred from the apparent disappearance of most of the population, probably due to chytridiomycosis.
assessor: Pounds, J., Puschendorf, R., Bolaños, F., Chaves, G., Crump, M., Solís, F., Ibáñez, R., Savage, J., Jaramillo, C., Fuenmayor, Q. & Lips, K.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

It seems probable that population declines in this species will continue into the east of the species range, whereby it may meet the Red List Criteria for Vulnerable or possibly Endangered during the next global assessment.

taxonomicnotes: This species might be a colour morph of Mantella baroni (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its Extent of Occurrence is less than 20,000 km2, all individuals are in fewer than ten locations, and there is likely to be continuing decline in the extent and quality of its forest habitat in southeastern Madagascar.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S. & Cox, N.A.

taxonomicnotes: This species and Mantella crocea might represent colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm.; Chiari et al. 2004). Populations with intermediate characteristics between Mantella crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004). The taxonomy of this species and of Mantella manery have been confused by amateurs using pseudo-scientific names in the pet-trade literature before the species were properly described.
rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its area of occupancy is probably less than 10 km², its distribution is severely fragmented, and the extent of its forest habitat in east-central Madagascar is probably declining.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S. & Cox, N.A.

taxonomicnotes: This species was inadvertently named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists of Threatened Species. This species is named from the Nicobar Islands, and it is very likely that the animals on these islands will prove to be different from the populations in Southeast Asia (I. Das pers. comm.). In addition, the animals designated as Hylarana nicobariensis in the Thai-Malay Peninsula are a very different taxon from the 'nicobariensis' in Java and Bali, Indonesia.

taxonomicnotes: Distinctiveness of nominal subspecies has not been confirmed by genetic data. Subspecies diastictus was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but he did not present any data to support this proposal. Frost (2007) recognized Pseudotriton diastictus as a distinct species but did not cite any data to support this arrangement. Crother (2008) retained diastictus as a subspecies of Pseudotriton montanus. Pending further data, this database includes diastictus as a subspecies of Pseudotriton montanus.
rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
evaluator: Stuart, S.N., Chanson, J.S., Cox, N.A. & Young, B.E.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its Area of Occupancy is probably less than 500km2, its distribution is severely fragmented, and the extent of its breeding habitat, the number of sub-populations, and the number of mature individuals, in southern United States and northeastern Mexico is declining.

taxonomicnotes: E. palustre is known to hybridize with a number of other species of the genus, none of these hybrids is frequent and they are not considered likely to affect the survival of the species or this evaluation.
rationale: This species is assessed as Least Concern as it is extremely widespread with locally common and stable subpopulations and does not face any major threats.
assessor: Akhani, H., Zehzad, B. & Brummitt, N.

rationale: Although there is habitat degradation across the range of Equisetum telmateia, this is not currently affecting the status of this species or threatening its survival; it does not meet any of the IUCN criteria for threatened or Near Threatened status and hence Least Concern is the most appropriate category for this species.
assessor: Akhani, H., Zehzad, B. & Brummitt, N.

taxonomicnotes: Isoetes coromandelina L. has two subspecies.: coromandelina L. and macrotubercolata C.R. Marsden
rationale: This species is widespread, but wetland habitats, in general, are threatened throughout the species' distribution range. However, this is not quantified or well documented and due to the wide distribution of the species, it is assessed as Least Concern. Immediate surveys and monitoring of habitats and populations throughout the species' range is recommended, especially within southern India. The species is likely to become locally extinct in southern India although more evidence is needed to confirm this.
evaluator: Manju, C.N., Rajesh, K.P., Jeeva, S., Irudayaraj, V. & Molur, S.

rationale: Asplenium jahandiezii is found in eight localities, with more than 100,000 individuals, an extent of occurrence of 830 km² and an area of occupancy of 20-30 km². The populations seem to be stable as well as its cliff habitat but there are potential threats from climbing. As currently no continuing decline is evident, this plant is assessed as Near Threatened approaching Criterion D2.

taxonomicnotes: Also referred to as Struthiopteris eburnea (H.Christ) Ching.

rationale: Bolbitis appendiculata is a lithophytic fern occurring patchily in several locations across southern, eastern and northeastern India extending eastwards into Asia. The species, although occasional, is widespread globally with a few identified threats in southern India. The status as per information available seems to be of Least Concern, but further studies on the threats and impacts on the species across its range are urgently required.
evaluator: Irudayaraj, V., Jeeva, S. & Molur, S.

taxonomicnotes: Long considered a separate species having a close relationship to the Wildcat, Felis silvestris, based on morphology (Garcia-Perea 2000, Wozencraft 2005). Based on genetic analysis, Driscoll et al. (2007) classified it as a Wildcat subspecies, F. silvestris bieti. Estimated time of divergence was recent (230,000 years BP), and further study is warranted before this classification can be definitely accepted.
rationale: The Chinese Mountain Cat has a restricted distribution in China, occurring on the eastern edge of the Tibetan plateau at elevations from 2,500-5,000 m (He et al. 2004). There is little information about its ecology and status (Yin et al. 2007, Wozencraft et al. 2008), but it is generally considered rare (Nowell and Jackson 1996). It is threatened primarily by large-scale poisoning campaigns targeting pikas, presumably their main prey (Nowell and Jackson 1996, He et al. 2004, Chen et al. 2005, Yin et al. 2008). Skins have also been seen in trade (Nowell and Jackson 1996, Chen et al. 2005). Its effective population size may be fewer than 10,000 mature breeding individuals, with a declining trend due to loss of prey base and persecution, and it may largely exist as a single interconnected subpopulation. Further information on distribution and status may warrant reclassification to a higher category of threat (IUCN Cats Red List workshop 2007).
assessor: Sanderson, J., Mallon, D.P. & Driscoll, C.
evaluator: Hoffmann, M., Nowell, K., Breitenmoser, U. & Breitenmoser-Wursten, C.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it is known from only one island, the island where it occurs is not known to be inhabited by humans. The species is not considered to be at particular risk from invasive species introductions or from hurricanes and other natural disasters.
evaluator: Cox, N., Chanson, J.S. & Stuart, S.N. (Global Reptile Assessment Coordinating Team)

evaluator: Cox, N., Chanson, J.S. & Stuart, S.N. (Global Reptile Assessment Coordinating Team)

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although it is known only from one island, the island is not known to be inhabited by humans, and the species is not considered to be at particular risk from invasive species introductions or from hurricanes and other natural disasters.
evaluator: Cox, N., Chanson, J.S. & Stuart, S.N. (Global Reptile Assessment Coordinating Team)

taxonomicnotes:
Puntius sarana subnasutus was originally described as Barbus subnasutus from Pondicherry by Valenciennes in Cuvier and Valenciennes (1842) from Pondicherry, India. Menon (1963) synonymized the species with Puntius sarana but considered it as a valid subspecies. Menon (1999) considered this species as Barbodes sarana subnasutus. Eschmeyer and Fricke (2011) have synonymized this species with Puntius sarana. However, the subspecies is valid in Jayaram (2010).

Further taxonomic investigation, especially using molecular techniques, is recommended.
rationale: Puntius sarana subnasutus is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed in the peninsular India with no known major threats to the species. However it is necessary to establish its proper taxonomic status.
evaluator: Rema Devi, K.R., Gopalakrishnan, A., Arunachalam, M., Shrikant, J., Johnson, J.A., Rahul, K. & Livingstone, S.

taxonomicnotes: The species and subspecies is still under review by the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2014). The species is frequently found in both Pulsatilla and Anemone genera.
rationale:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The species has a wide but fragmented geographical distribution from southeastern France, southern Switzerland and Poland, extending eastwards to Greece, Bulgaria and Ukraine. Some subspecies are considered to be rare in several countries. There are no known widespread threats across its range, but it is vulnerable to changes in the management of pastures, and may be locally impacted by collection from the wild.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at c.81,000 km2, which exceeds the threshold for a threatened category. Based on available point data, it is not possible to calculate and estimate a reliable area of occupancy (AOO).

Although the species or its subspecies has been assessed as threatened in some countries across its range, it is considered Least Concern here as it has a wide geographical range with and EOO that greatly exceeds the threshold for a threatened category, and there are no known widespread threats. Since some populations are growing in high altitude, they are to some extent protected from natural afforestation and urbanization impacts. The species should be reassessed if population data become available that show decline across the range of the species.
